<0> How can I purchase savings bonds? The U.S. Treasury Department is converting from issuing paper bonds to issuing bonds electronically and the process of purchasing savings bonds by payroll deduction for Federal employees and military members will soon end. To start or continue purchasing savings bonds, you will need to establish an individual account at Treasury Direct Website. After you establish your account at Treasury Direct Website, use myPay to establish an allotment to your account at Treasury Direct for purchase of savings bonds. Information on establishing a TreasuryDirect account is available at Treasury Direct Website; view the link about how to buy using Treasury Direct payroll savings. View the Treasury Direct FAQs about the elimination of paper bonds via payroll savings. For military members with current bond allotments, DFAS will automatically stop your bond allotment at the end of July. However, if you have a multi-month bond (purchase requires more than one month's deduction) that can be fully purchased by the end of August, it will be allowed to continue until that date and then the allotment will be stopped. For civilian employees, payroll deduction for bonds will stop as of 29 August 2010. For both military and civilian employees, you will be refunded any amount that was deducted but not used to purchase a bond. In addition, you'll see an increase in your net pay as a result of discontinuing the bond allotment. For active duty members with bonds held in safekeeping by DFAS, they will remain in safekeeping until you leave active duty or until you request release of the bonds. </0> <1> How long will a debt collection take to post to my military and/or travel pay record? Military Pay Debts (Active Duty): You should see the collection posted to Leave and Earnings Statement (LES) within two pay periods of when you remitted the collection; this is due to military pay cut-offs.
Military Pay Debts (Reservist): You should see the collection posted to your LES within 30 days of when you remitted the collection; this is due to military pay cut-offs.
Travel Pay Debts (Active, Civilian and Reservist): Check Payment: If you mail a check to the AFFSC, then it should be posted to your Travel record within 30 days of mailing check.
Payroll Deduction (Active): If you elect payroll deduction to settle your travel debt, then the collection will start within two pay periods based on documentation submission to AFFSC. You will see a detailed debt transaction on your LES. Your travel record will record the individual collections as they are received. Payroll Deduction (Reservist): If you chose payroll deduction to settle your travel debt, then the debt will start to collect upon posting to your military pay record and a deduction will be made when you perform your next paid duty period. You will see a detailed debt transaction on your LES. Payroll Deduction (Civilian): You can pay your Civilian PCS travel debt back in installments by submitting a signed voluntary repayment statement through your servicing Civilian Pay Office Refer to DODFMR Vol 8 Chap 8 (Civilian Pay - Underpayments and Indebtedness) for additional information on civilian payroll deductions Military Pay Debts (Active Duty): You should see the collection posted to Leave and Earnings Statement (LES) within two pay periods of when you remitted the collection; this is due to military pay cut-offs.
Military Pay Debts (Reservist): You should see the collection posted to your LES within 30 days of when you remitted the collection; this is due to military pay cut-offs.
Travel Pay Debts (Active, Civilian and Reservist): Check Payment: If you mail a check to the AFFSC, then it should be posted to your Travel record within 30 days of mailing check.
Payroll Deduction (Active): If you elect payroll deduction to settle your travel debt, then the collection will start within two pay periods based on documentation submission to AFFSC. You will see a detailed debt transaction on your LES. Your travel record will record the individual collections as they are received. Payroll Deduction (Reservist): If you chose payroll deduction to settle your travel debt, then the debt will start to collect upon posting to your military pay record and a deduction will be made when you perform your next paid duty period. You will see a detailed debt transaction on your LES. Payroll Deduction (Civilian): You can pay your Civilian PCS travel debt back in installments by submitting a signed voluntary repayment statement through your servicing Civilian Pay Office Refer to DODFMR Vol 8 Chap 8 (Civilian Pay - Underpayments and Indebtedness) for additional information on civilian payroll deductions

</1> <2> How do I start Incentive Pays such as Parachute Duty (Jump Pay), Flight Deck Duty, Demolition Duty, Experimental Stress Duty, or other Incentive Pays? Please see below if you believe you are entitled to these incentive pays: Parachute Duty (Jump Pay) - Your Host Aviation Resource Management (HARM) Office will provide start and stop notification to your FSO Flight Deck Hazardous Duty Pay (FDHDP) - Your FSO prepares the start transaction based on special orders assigning a member to flight deck duty Demolition Duty - Your FSO processes transactions based on a letter prepared by your unit commander Experimental Stress Duty - Your FSO processes transactions based on assignment orders from your unit Other Incentive Pays - FSO processes transactions based on orders received from your unit
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 23 (Parachute Duty, Flight Deck Duty, Demolition Duty, Experimental Stress Duty and Other Incentive Pays) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437185000&usg=AFQjCNFMzO1Ipdgoq_ddZUNCD243EFkqqQ
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 23 (Parachute Duty, Flight Deck Duty, Demolition Duty, Experimental Stress Duty and Other Incentive Pays) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437185000&usg=AFQjCNFMzO1Ipdgoq_ddZUNCD243EFkqqQ
</2> <3> Why is my BAH different from someone at my duty location who has the same rank as I do? If you are receiving a different BAH allowance than someone from the same duty location that has the same rank as you, BAH Rate Protection is probably in effect for one of you. The monthly BAH amount must not be reduced as a result of changes in housing costs in the MHA (Military Housing Area), changes in the national monthly housing cost, or a member's promotion. One of you is most likely receiving a higher BAH in an area where there was a BAH reduction. This grandfathering protects the member from BAH fluctuations. To check the rate of BAH for your PDS (Note, BAH is based on your PDS Zip Code, not your home Zip Code) and rank, please visit DTMO's BAH Rates web site. However, if you believe this is not the case (i.e. the rate in your area did not decrease and you are not subject to BAH Rate Protection), then you should immediately contact your servicing Finance Office to ensure you are not over or under paid.
Regulation: $JTR_Chap_10_Part_APara10004

</3> <4> How can I get copies of old travel vouchers? For vouchers that were created and processed electronically through the Defense Travel System (DTS), you can view and print your paid travel vouchers by accessing DTS. For non-DTS vouchers such as PCS and most deployment travel, when the voucher is paid, a copy is emailed to you at the address on file in the Reserve Travel System (RTS). If you didn't get a copy, it could be that an incorrect email address is on file in RTS or there could have been a delay in processing your voucher. You should contact your servicing Finance Office for assistance and to check your RTS email address. If you are looking for a voucher filed at a different duty location, you should contact that base for help in retrieving old voucher copies. You can use our FSO Look-up Tool to find the contact information for the FSO at different locations. Please note that the statute of limitations on travel voucher retention by the FSO is 6 years and 3 months. It is unlikely you will be able to retrieve voucher copies beyond that time frame, so therefore it is important to always save a digital or hard copy of all filed travel vouchers in your personal records.

</4> <5> Who do I make the check for my debt out to? Travel Debts: Make your check payable to: DSSN 3801 and mail to: Air Force Financial Services Center, 2700 Doolittle Dr. Suite 113, Ellsworth AFB, SD 57706.
Military Pay Debts:
Active Duty: Make your check payable to: US Treasury - DSSN 3801 and submit to your servicing Finance Office.
Reserve: Either submit your check to your servicing Finance Office or mail your check to DFAS at the following address. This address is effective 1 August 2008. Disbursing Operations Directorate 3801 Center Collections PO Box 269490 Indianapolis, IN 46249

</5> <6> How is my Dislocation Allowance (DLA) paid? DLA is paid via EFT to your direct deposit account, or you can charge up to your entitled DLA amount on your Government Travel Charge Card (GTCC). When possible, members should use their GTCC to cover their PCS expenses. To file a claim for DLA, please use eFinance. For Reservists, your orders must state that PCS entitlements are authorized. To calculate your DLA, please use our Military PCS Calculator. DLA is paid via EFT to your direct deposit account, or you can charge up to your entitled DLA amount on your Government Travel Charge Card (GTCC). When possible, members should use their GTCC to cover their PCS expenses. To file a claim for DLA, please use eFinance. For Reservists, your orders must state that PCS entitlements are authorized. To calculate your DLA, please use our Military PCS Calculator.

</6> <7> What will I receive for a receipt for my debt payment? Active Duty: If you make a payment in person at the local Finance Office for a military pay debt, you will get a copy of the collection voucher. Collection of military pay debts will also be on your LES. For travel debts, you mail your payment to the AFFSC at Ellsworth AFB, SD, and your receipt will be your cancelled check.
Reserve: For military pay debts, if you mail your payment to DFAS, your cancelled check is your receipt. If you mail a payment to the AFFSC for a travel debt, your cancelled check will be your receipt.
Civilians: When you mail a payment to the AFFSC for a travel debt, your cancelled check will be your receipt.

</7> <8> When will my Dislocation Allowance (DLA) be paid? Generally, DLA is paid upon final settlement of your PCS voucher. If you are exempt from Government Travel Charge Card (GTCC) use and you have dependents who are relocating, you may receive an advance of DLA not earlier than 10 days prior to PCS departure. To file a claim for DLA, please use eFinance. For Reservists, your orders must state that PCS allowances are authorized. To calculate your DLA, please use our Military PCS Calculator.
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 9 Chap 3 Para 030501 (Use of the GTCC for official government travel) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437189000&usg=AFQjCNGSstyHtFpnDQ-NM5GXxivb8lEy_w

</8> <9> How will I get paid as a new reservist? Effective 1 September 1989, participation in the direct deposit program became mandatory for all new Air Force active duty, ANG, Air Reserve members, and those members reenlisting or gaining officer status after that date. If the member is not enrolled in the Direct Deposit of Pay Program, DFAS-DE prepares and mails checks to member’s personal mailing address. Waivers for non-participation in the Direct Deposit of Pay Program may be granted by the unit and/or installation commander. Waivers may be granted upon an individual’s request, or may be commander-directed due to circumstances in which participation in the Direct Deposit of Pay Program is not feasible or practical. A waiver issued by the unit commander at the member’s request may not exceed six months. A waiver of greater than six months must be approved by the unit’s higher headquarters or the installation commander, whichever is applicable. The Direct Deposit of Pay Waiver Report, UH022-302, is sent monthly to each unit to identify non-participation and whether a waiver has been approved and if so, when it expires.
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 3 Chap 7.1 (Reserve Component: Checks and Direct Deposit - Payment Options) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/production/1/saf_fm/publication/afman65-116v3/afman65-116v3.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437189000&usg=AFQjCNFWZoMC80f6s6CciLoj7-uC08ViwQ
</9> <10> What locations are authorized Hostile Fire Pay/Imminent Danger Pay (HFP/IDP) and Combat Zone Tax Exclusion (CZTE)? A listing of locations authorized HFP/IDP can be found in the DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 10 Figure 10-1 (Designated Hostile Fire or Imminent Danger Pay Areas). A listing of locations authorized CZTE (Combat Zone Tax Exemption) can be found in the DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 44 Figure 44-2 (Collection of Delinquet Taxes by Installment - Change of Member's Status). To estimate your entitlements during your deployment, please use the Deployment Allowances Calculator.

</10> <11> Why are there no taxes taken out of my annual SRB payment? If you reenlisted during a month when you were entitled to Combat Zone Tax Exclusion (CZTE) your bonus and all subsequent installment payments will not be taxed. Please visit your Finance Office if your bonus was not taxed and you did not reenlist during a month when you were entitled to CZTE.

</11> <12> How do I initiate Family Separation Housing - Overseas housing allowance based location (FSH-O)? To start FSH-O, contact the Housing Office / Billeting Office to complete a DD Form 2367 (Individual OHA Report). Bring the completed DD Form 2367 (Individual OHA Report) to your servicing Finance Office to start FSH-O..
For Reservists, if you are called to active duty for a contingency, you are authorized Overseas Housing Allowance (OHA) regardless of timeframe. For all other tours of more than 30 days you are entitled to OHA. Please contact your servicing Finance Office to initiate FSH-O.

</12> <13> How do I report Government Travel Charge Card (GTCC) abuse? Active Duty: See your Unit Agency Program Coordinator (APC) or your Commander's Support Staff (CSS) to report GTCC abuse.
Reserve: See your appointed Agency Program Coordinator (APC) and Squadron leadership to report GTCC abuse.
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 9 Chap 3 Para 030103 (GTCC Regulation compliance) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437193000&usg=AFQjCNGgjyV6OWAgwYqWlPdnWKfkmVsFKg

</13> <14> How long does the decision process take for my remission/waiver application? Normally, you should receive a decision within approximately 90 days. Your servicing Financial Office is required to follow up on your remission/waiver application after 45 days of submission by the Finance Office to the decision authority.
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 73 Sec 73B 73.8.3 (Waivers - FSO Actions) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437193000&usg=AFQjCNH20XsKH2X2aqsWsdsbt-w4Fs29IA

</14> <15> Why didn't I receive full Meals and Incidental Expenses (M&IE) on the first and last day of my TDY? Full per diem is not authorized on the first or last day of TDY. When TDY, regardless of the meal rate authorized in your orders, you are only authorized 75% of the appropriate M&IE rate on the day of your departure from PDS, and on the day of return to your PDS.
The appropriate M&IE rate in these instances will be the rate from your last TDY or authorized delay point. Any TDY en route locations, on the day travel ends, does not affect the M&IE rate for that return day unless overnight lodging is required.

DFAS will email the statement to you through your Finance office within 1 to 2 weeks, normally.

</18> <19> What do I need to submit with my Relocation Income Tax Allowance (RITA) claim? To file for RITA, complete and submit the following documents: DD Form 1351-2 (Travel Voucher or Sub Voucher), signed and dated. Relocation Income Tax (RIT) Allowance Status Certification Form. One copy of each W-2 form for earned income from the year in which the traveler is paid PCS travel claim payments. If filing a joint return, include spouse's/domestic partner's W-2 form for earned income from the year in which you were paid PCS travel claim payments. If applicable, one copy of the IRS Schedule SE from self-employment income. If filing a joint return, include spouse/domestic partner information as well. One copy of DD Form 1614 (PCS Travel Orders), including all amendments. One copy of an IRS Form 1099-R, but only if for military retirement income (exclude interest income). You should receive a RITA package from the Air Force Financial Services Center (AFFSC) shortly after the beginning of the calendar year providing detailed guidance on what is to be included in the claim submission.

</20> <21> As a Reservist, how do I take or cancel leave? To take leave, you must complete an AF IMT 988 (Leave Request/Authorization), which must be signed by your current supervisor or your active duty supervisor, and submitted to your Reserve Pay Office. To cancel leave, you must complete Part III of your existing AF IMT 988 (Leave Request/Authorization), reflecting your cancellation and have it signed by your supervisor and then submit to your Reserve Pay Office (RPO).

</25> <26> Am I eligible for First Assignment Instructor Pilot (FAIP) Dislocation Allowance (DLA)? First Assignment Instructor Pilot (FAIP) DLA is a category of partial DLA that exists for student pilots assigned to Air Education Training Command (AETC) locations. This partial DLA is payable when a student completes training and remains at that station as their first assignment. Full DLA is not authorized because the student is not on PCS orders, but a short distance Household Goods (HHG) move may be authorized at the government's expense when the student moves from the training dorms to permanent party dorms or housing with orders.

</26> <27> Does updating my EFT information in myPay update the information in Travel Pay systems as well? Currently the Air Force uses two travel pay systems: The Reserve Travel System (RTS) and the Defense Travel System (DTS).
For military members, unless you've previously designated a separate account for travel payments, updating your EFT information in myPay will automatically update your EFT information in RTS. However, it does not update your EFT information in DTS. To make this update, you must contact your Unit's Organizational Defense Travel Administrator (ODTA) for assistance. To designate a separate account for travel payments for non-DTS travel (RTS), please use eFinance. For Civilian personnel, updating your EFT information in myPay will not automatically update your EFT information in RTS. You need to contact your local Finance Office and complete a Standard Form 1199A (Direct Deposit Sign-Up) to have this information updated in RTS, and your unit ODTA to update DTS.

</28> <29> Is my family authorized to travel for Emergency Leave / Emergency Visitation Travel (EVT)? Uniformed Members: Yes, transportation allowances at government expense are authorized for both you and the dependents . Dependents who do not live with you at your overseas location are not eligible to receive Emergency Leave allowances. Civilian Employees: Yes, transportation allowances at government expense are authorized for you or one of your family members who reside with you at your OCONUS location. See JTR Chap 7 Part A Para 7020 (Civilian Employees - Emergency Visitation Travel - EVT) for additional family member exceptions.

If you are required to procure meals only during a TDY within the local area, you may be reimbursed for those meals up to the proportional meal rate.
To file a claim for reimbursement of expenditures on official business, please use eFinance.

Regardless of the change, provide copies all amendments (and original orders) with your TDY settlement voucher. To file a travel settlement voucher, please use eFinance.

</31> <32> How can I challenge a civilian PCS debt? If you do not agree with the amount or validity of the debt, you can contact your servicing Finance Office for an explanation of the voucher. A review and re-computation of the voucher will reveal if the debt is either correct or incorrect.
If the debt is incorrect, a supplemental voucher will need to be processed to make the correction. Depending on the source of the error, you may need to prepare a supplemental voucher using DD Form 1351-2, Travel Voucher or Sub voucher.
If the debt is determined to be correct, you have the option of requesting a waiver of the debt from your Civilian Payroll Office. In order to do that, a DD Form 139 will need to be prepared by the AFFSC and forwarded to Civilian Payroll to establish the debt on your pay record. At that point you can work with Civilian Payroll to process the waiver request. Waivers are forwarded to DFAS for review and adjudication.
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 8 Chap 8 (Civilian Pay - Underpayments and Indebtedness) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437202000&usg=AFQjCNGVGftVBCQyhQ2f0CX0fOebUMnJkw
</32> <33> How much leave do I earn as a reservist? For active duty tours of 30 consecutive days or more, you accrue leave at the rate of one-half (1/2) calendar day for every 6 days on active duty in a pay status, with a maximum of two and one-half (2 1/2) calendar days for each 30 consecutive days, including allowable travel time. You do not accrue leave for periods of duty in a non-pay status or for tours less than 30 days. If you are on back-to-back tours (no break in orders), leave will accrue and can be rolled over until the end of the back-to-back orders. Any leave not used during the confines of the last back-to-back order, must be sold back when that order ends. Typically, the accrued leave must be used before the end of your active duty tour. For example, if you are on an active duty tour from 2 March through 30 April, your accrued leave must be taken before 1 May. Please see your Reserve Pay Office for exceptions to this rule.
If there is any unused accrued leave remaining at the end of your tour, it must be sold. Once your Reserve Pay Office receives your completed AF Form IMT 938 (Request and Authorization for Active Duty Training/Active Duty Tour), they will process a transaction to generate payment of your remaining leave balance. Typically, the leave will be paid 10-16 days following input by your Reserve Pay Office. Contact your Reserve Pay Office regarding local policies concerning sell back requirements. Check your Leave and Earnings Statement (LES) via myPay for your current leave balance. Note: Exceptions to the leave payment policy apply during contingency operations; please contact your Reserve Pay Office for details to your specific situation.
Regulation: AFI 36-3003 Sec B 4.4 (Leave Accrual) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/production/1/af_a1/publication/afi36-3003/afi36-3003.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437202000&usg=AFQjCNGk74sj2v8FZiXa9M0y_SrGSRObsw

</34> <35> Can I be reimbursed for two different lodging receipts for the same day? Yes, you may claim dual lodging to cover lodging expenses that arise because of unexpected circumstances beyond your control during TDY travel. Dual lodging must be approved after the fact by an amended authorization/order or by your AO on your travel voucher. The AO will verify that you acted reasonably and prudently in determining if it was necessary for you to obtain dual lodgings for other than personal convenience. Dual lodging reimbursement is limited to a maximum of 7 consecutive days through AO approval. Dual lodging over 7 days must be approved by the Secretarial Process. To file your settlement travel voucher, please use Defense Travel System (DTS). To file your non-DTS settlement travel voucher, please use eFinance.

</35> <36> How long does it take to process a TDY advance? Once you submit your advance request it normally takes 7 to 10 business days to receive payment via Electronic Funds Transfer (EFT). If you have a Government Travel Charge Card (GTCC), you cannot get advances from the Finance Office. You would simply withdraw cash from ATMs as needed during your TDY. To request your advance, please use Defense Travel System (DTS). To request your non-DTS advance, please use eFinance.

</36> <37> How much base pay am I entitled to receive when performing Inactive Duty Training (IDT)/Unit Training Assembly (UTA)? Your base pay, also called basic pay, will vary based on how many IDT/UTA periods you perform for each pay cycle. Pay grade and years of service also affect your basic pay. For a current list of basic pay amounts, refer to the drill pay page within the DFAS Military Pay Tables. For further help contact your servicing Finance Office.

Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 58 (Pay and Allowances for Inactive Duty Training) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437205000&usg=AFQjCNFOAov4J4MZdlTJctcG42KQnmxbBQ

</37> <38> Am I allowed to bring dependents back if they leave early under early return of dependents (ERD) orders? Uniformed Members: Yes; however, in most cases return of the dependent(s) will be at the member's expense. Civilian Employees: Yes; however, once dependents travel on ERD orders certain limitations apply (see JTR Chap 5_Part_B_Sec_3c (Civilian Employees - Dependent Travel - Early Return of Dependents) for more information): A dependent’s early return travel under Chapter 5 must not be authorized more than once during each period of OCONUS service A dependent’s return travel at GOV’T expense to the OCONUS PDS is not authorized except when incident to the employee’s Renewal Agreement Travel (RAT). See par. 7065. A dependent’s early return transportation expenses to the OCONUS PDS are reimbursable when an employee:
Completes an agreed to period of service Has received unaccompanied one-way dependent transportation to the actual residence Has RAT at a later date Reimbursement must not exceed the GOV’T's cost for the usual transportation mode and route that would have been used had the dependent traveled back to the OCONUS PDS with the employee
Regulation: JTR Chap 5_Part_A_Sec_3a (Uniformed Members - Dependent Travel and Transportation) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/travelreg.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437205000&usg=AFQjCNG1uBgHsPaH-D16SDUqlUib3ZwvSg
Regulation: JTR Chap 5_Part_B_Sec_3c (Civilian Employees - Dependent Travel - Early Return of Dependents) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/travelreg.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437205000&usg=AFQjCNG1uBgHsPaH-D16SDUqlUib3ZwvSg
Regulation: JTR Chap 5_Part_B_Sec_3c (Civilian Employees - Dependent Travel - Early Return of Dependents) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/travelreg.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437205000&usg=AFQjCNG1uBgHsPaH-D16SDUqlUib3ZwvSg
</38> <39> How does hospitalization affect my tax free status? If you are hospitalized, or rehospitalized, because of a wound, disease or injury that you incurred while serving in a combat zone, your tax free status (combat zone tax exclusion (CZTE)) continues while you are hospitalized. Your exclusion ends when you are discharged from the hospital or changed to outpatient status. If you are rehospitalized due to the same injury you may also qualify for the tax exclusion for up to two years after hostilities have ended. Reference DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 44 Para 440103C7 link below and the Wounded Warrior Handbook, published by DFAS. There are additional support materials on the DFAS Wounded Warrior website.
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 44 Para 440103C7 https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437205000&usg=AFQjCNFOAov4J4MZdlTJctcG42KQnmxbBQ
Related Link: DFAS Wounded Warrior https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.dfas.mil/militarymembers/woundedwarrior/woundedwarriorpay.html&sa=D&ust=1558682437206000&usg=AFQjCNHruVVYjbZiwMD3k6XK-7xYu4HLEQ
Related Link: Wounded Warrior Handbook https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.dfas.mil/militarymembers/woundedwarrior/woundedwarriorpay.html&sa=D&ust=1558682437206000&usg=AFQjCNHruVVYjbZiwMD3k6XK-7xYu4HLEQ
</39> <40> How do I withdraw money from my Thrift Savings Plan (TSP) account? For information about withdrawing money from your TSP account, visit the Thrift Savings Plan Website. The site provides information that you should consider depending on the type of withdrawal that you want to make, such as for financial hardship, age-based, or an in-service withdrawal. In addition to the website, you may also call a TSP Representative at 1-TSP-YOU-FRST (1-877-968-3778).
Related Link: Thrift Savings Plan Website https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.tsp.gov/&sa=D&ust=1558682437206000&usg=AFQjCNGFg1g3tTz-iwmyarFiaX8zL7k1Wg
Related Link: Thrift Savings Plan Website https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.tsp.gov/&sa=D&ust=1558682437206000&usg=AFQjCNGFg1g3tTz-iwmyarFiaX8zL7k1Wg
</40> <41> Why do I have to re-certify my Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH)? Service regulations require everyone who receives BAH on behalf of their dependents to submit a certification to their servicing RPO. The certification is completed by filling out an AF Form 594 (Application and Authorization to start, stop or change BAQ or Dependency Re-determination). The certification must indicate the status of each dependent to the military sponsor. You are required to complete an initial certification, and then review and re-certify your dependent status every three years or immediately upon change of dependency status.
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 3 Chap 14.8 (Reserve Component: Entitlement Recertificaion) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/production/1/saf_fm/publication/afman65-116v3/afman65-116v3.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437206000&usg=AFQjCNEmFWaqc8DUL_w7D3Bq__oeQnkf-A
Regulation: $JTR_Chap_10_Part_BPara10100C
Regulation: $JTR_Chap_10_Part_BPara10100D
Form: AF Form 594 (Application and Authorization to start, stop or change BAQ or Dependency Re-determination) to review this form you must first download the E-Publishing Viewer
</41> <42> How do I repay a Reserve military pay debt? Reserve members assigned to an organization with a Reserve disbursing function may pay via check payable to US Treasury - DSSN 3801. Reserve members not co-located with a Reserve disbursing function mail their checks to DFAS at the following address. This address is effective 1 August 2008.
Disbursing Operations Directorate 3801 Center Collections PO Box 269490 Indianapolis, IN 46249
You may also work with your Finance Office to establish a repayment schedule.
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 3 Chap 32.21 (Reserve Component: Collections) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/production/1/saf_fm/publication/afman65-116v3/afman65-116v3.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437207000&usg=AFQjCNGeHHPnlCmNKwXbup2eAM_v0HuOxw
</42> <43> Am I authorized to stay at the port for Renewal Agreement Travel (RAT)? Your travel must be arranged by the Commercial Travel Office (CTO) and if the CTO schedule requires you to remain at the port overnight, you will be authorized per diem. Per diem is not authorized for an employee's dependents for RAT when the employee will return to the same OCONUS PDS for duty.
Regulation: JTR Chap 7 Part A Para 7065 (Civilian Employees Only - Renewal Agreement Travel - RAT) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/travelreg.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437207000&usg=AFQjCNF_ovJhgHeRRGJtF9KUOfdeMcQgcw
</43> <44> How do I withdraw funds from my Thrift Savings Plan (TSP) once I retire? There are two ways to request a fund withdrawal from TSP: 1. Complete a TSP-U-70 (Request for Full Withdrawal) form or use the online TSP-U-70 Wizard (click first link on #3) to fill out the form and mail it to: Thrift Savings Plan P.O. Box 385021 Birmingham, AL 35238 You may also fax the completed form to 1-800-817-5023. 2. Go to the Thrift Savings Plan Website to begin the withdrawal process.

</44> <45> My January LES shows Combat Zone Tax Exclusion (CZTE) for December, why didn't I get my tax refunded? When a retroactive transaction is processed that adjusts your prior year federal and state wages, a corrected W-2 will be issued to reflect the change in taxable wages. In this particular case, the adjustment reduced your taxable wages; however, because it is for a prior year, we cannot refund the taxes to you directly. When you file the corrected W-2 with your tax return, the reduction of your taxable wages decreases your tax liability, and increases the amount of any refund that may be due to you. If you need to request a corrected W-2, contact your servicing Finance Office for assistance.
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 56 Sec 56D 56.27.2.1.3 (CZTE - Retroactive Effective Date) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437208000&usg=AFQjCNHXYHOda0vJJYSjO_iKDCHICoEbiw

</45> <46> Why didn't I get my anniversary Civilian Clothing Allowance? You may not have received it yet because the allowance is not paid until the end of your anniversary month. However, if it is projected that you will not remain on your current enlistment more than six months beyond your anniversary month, then the replacement Civilian Clothing Allowance is not authorized, and it will not be paid.
If you are assigned to a duty station or career field that qualifies for Civilian Clothing Allowance and you have received an annual replacement allowance before, but have yet to receive it this year, please contact your servicing Finance Office.

</46> <47> How often can I get a maternity clothing allowance? You can receive a maternity clothing allowance no more than once every three years. You can find current rates for the maternity clothing allowance in DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 29 Table 29-6 (AF Supplementary Clothing Allowances).

</47> <48> Do I receive an extra clothing allowance for my Physical Training (PT) uniforms? No, PT uniforms are a part of your initial clothing issue. Your annual clothing replacement allowance is provided to maintain your initial issue throughout your career.

</48> <49> How do I find out if I am entitled to leave sell back resulting from appellate review leave? If you're directed to take appellate review leave, you can elect to be paid for leave you've accrued up to the day before your appellate review leave starts. Alternatively, you could elect to receive normal pay and allowances until your accrued leave is used. For the period of appellate review leave after your accrued leave is either used or sold, you will be in an unpaid excess leave status. You will not accrue leave while awaiting appellate review.
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 44.6.4 (Supplemental Procedures for Appellate Review Leave, Type R) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437210000&usg=AFQjCNFQDdVX6vtLvAxwU5nLuKczSMlQNA

</49> <50> I have a travel debt, what per diem rate was I paid? Review your travel voucher summary for the per diem rate(s) you were paid.
If you think you were paid an incorrect per diem rate, compare the TDY points on your voucher summary to the per diem rate listed on the Per Diem Rates website.
For Reservists, your duty status will determine if you were entitled to receive per diem during your TDY.
If you have questions about how your voucher was computed, please contact your servicing Finance Office.

</50> <51> Can my Government Travel Charge Card (GTCC) be paid off from my accrual payment? Yes, when you prepare your accrual worksheet there is a split disbursement field to indicate the amount which you would like to send directly to your GTCC account. You can either use eFinance or vMPF to request your accrual

</51> <52> Why did my Government Travel Charge Card (GTCC) stop working? The three most common reasons that your card can not be used are: Your card's limit has been reached Your account is over 60 days delinquent and your Agency Program Coordinator (APC) suspended the card Your card expired The card issuer's phone agents or your APC can give you the specifics of your situation and your APC can assist in correcting the issue. If you are stranded while on official business, call the 1-800 number on the back of the GTCC and identify yourself as a stranded Department of Defense (DoD) traveler.
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 9 Chap 3 Para 031302 (GTCC Delinquency Management - Suspension of Accounts 61 days past billing) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437211000&usg=AFQjCNFOZL_0m69Fm_3x8sHVDeHEscKmig

</52> <53> How do I request an additional travel advance for my civilian PCS? The standard practice for receiving an advance is to use your Government Travel Charge Card (GTCC) at an ATM machine.
If you do not have a GTCC, or you are a member of the collective bargaining unit not yet required to use a GTCC, then you will need to go to your Finance Office and request an advance paid via Electronic Funds Transfer (EFT). You will need to prepare a DD Form 1351-2 and submit through eFinance. If you need more help with your Civilian PCS advance contact your Finance Office.
If you did receive an advance via EFT, the advance will be deducted when you file your PCS settlement travel voucher at your new duty station.
Regulation: AFI 65-114 Chap 9.3.3 (Civilian Employee Permanent Change of Station) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/production/1/saf_fm/publication/afi65-114/afi65-114.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437212000&usg=AFQjCNFZUdjzpPJ6pMva-K9CK3VOoyYEvw

</53> <54> How do I repay my emergency (partial/casual) payment? Your partial/casual payment is automatically deducted in full from your next available paycheck. For Reservists, you must be on a tour of 30 days or more to be eligible for a partial / casual payment.
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 36.4 (Special Provisions - Casual Payments) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437212000&usg=AFQjCNGXTEX-IQVrDpaS_N-0t_59g7KHVA
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 36.5 (Partial Payments) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437212000&usg=AFQjCNGXTEX-IQVrDpaS_N-0t_59g7KHVA

</54> <55> If I don't know my Government Travel Charge Card (GTCC) balance, will finance know it? No. The easiest way to get your current GTCC balance is to contact Citibank directly. </64> <65> What are my dependents’ living expense allowances at a safe haven location incident to an authorized evacuation? Safe haven evacuation allowances for your command-sponsored dependents are provided to assist meeting the excess costs involved in temporarily maintaining a separate residence for your dependents. First 30 days: Each dependent 12 years old or older (including your spouse) is authorized 100% of the per diem rate for meals & incidental expense (M&IE) and up to 100% of the lodging rate for the safe haven location. Each dependent under 12 years old is authorized 50% of the per diem rate for M&IE and up to 50% of the lodging rate for the safe haven location. Note: Lodging tax is reimbursed separately. Example: Spouse, a child over 12, and 2 children under 12 evacuate to a safe haven location with an M&IE rate of $46 and a max lodging rate of $77 per day. The spouse and the child over 12 are each authorized 100% of the M&IE rate ($46 x 100% x 2 = $92/day). The 2 children under 12 are each authorized 50% of the M&IE rate ($46 x 50% x 2 = $46/day). Lodging can be reimbursed for the entire family up to 300% (100% + 100% + 50% + 50% = 300%) of the max lodging rate per day (300% x $77 = $231/day). Day 31 – 180 Each dependent 12 years old or older (including your spouse) is authorized 60% of the per diem rate for M&IE and up to 60% of the lodging rate for the safe haven location. Each dependent under 12 years old is authorized 30% of the per diem rate for M&IE and up to 30% of the lodging rate for the safe haven location.
Regulation: JTR Chap 6 Part A Para 6005 (Uniformed Members - Evacuation Allowance - General Information) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/travelreg.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437217000&usg=AFQjCNHRVbw7PwP-zjPv-tgrEM4UL2K3YA
Regulation: JTR Chap 6 Part A Para 6005 (Uniformed Members - Evacuation Allowance - General Information) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/travelreg.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437218000&usg=AFQjCNEseSAIQ0nM3uLLbU8cJX9IQke7uw
</65> <66> I paid the Montgomery GI Bill (MGIB) off, why didn't my pay check increase by $100? While your $100 MGIB deduction is collecting from your pay, your monthly taxable wage is reduced by the same $100. This results in less federal income tax being withheld from your pay. When your MGIB is fully collected, your monthly taxable wage increases by $100, resulting in more federal income tax being withheld from your pay. You will see the difference of the taxes withheld as in increase in your pay after the MGIB is fully collected.

</68> <69> What is earned income credit (EIC) and how do I apply for it? EIC is a tax credit for certain people who work and whose earned income is less than the threshold established by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). The EIC may reduce your income tax liability at the end of the year and may give you a refund even if you don't owe any tax.
Eligibility for EIC can be determined by completing the worksheet on the back of the W-5 Form (Earned Income Credit Advance Payment Certificate). If eligible, submit your completed W-5 to your Finance Office. Also, review the IRS Publication 596 at the link below.
Active Duty: If you file the W-5 Form before the end of the tax year with your Finance Office you may receive advance payment of the EIC in your pay. When you file your tax return at the end of the year, you claim any advance payment of EIC that you received and determine if there is any remaining credit due you.
Reserve: At the end of the tax year, claim the EIC when you file your tax return.

Very few exceptions exist to this policy. Please contact your servicing Finance Office to inquire about your specific circumstances. </75> <76> How do I claim a secondary dependent for Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH)? If you already have a primary dependent, then submitting paperwork for a secondary dependent has no impact on your BAH; however, you can still complete a dependency determination for other entitlements (ID card, medical, etc.). If your secondary dependent is your sole dependent for BAH purposes (or you are completing a dependency determination for other entitlements), then the following applies: To claim a secondary dependent you must complete AF Form 594 (Application and Authorization to start, stop or change BAQ or Dependency Re-determination). You must also complete the appropriate DD Form 137. You may receive these forms and assistance in filling them out from your finance office. Additionally, you must obtain supporting documents that establish the secondary dependent relationship and/or financial support. Written verification of the dependent's income, from all sources, is required. Accepted documents include, but are not limited to: pay stubs, Social Security documents and W-2s. When the dependent does not reside in your household, then proof of your support is also required. Accepted documents include, but are not limited to: canceled checks, money orders, receipts or a dependent support allotment. Due to a recent regulation change, you will personally send all documentation to DFAS for final determination. Please see the Dependency Determinations pamphlet in the File Attachments below for detailed instructions regarding secondary dependents, as well as the current mailing address for DFAS submissions.

</76> <77> What is the difference between a travel advance and a travel accrual? An advance is paid prior to your TDY departure date if you are exempt from using the Government Travel Charge Card (GTCC) and do not have a GTCC. Accrual payments are paid throughout a TDY (longer than 45 days) in 30 day increments at your request. Accruals may be pre-established prior to your departure from your PDS or requested as needed after your departure. You can use any of following options when requesting travel accruals establish payment prior to departure: eFinance, vMPF, fax, e-mail, or request accruals from your Finance Office. Both types of payments are deducted from your final travel voucher if you elect to receive them. To file your advance or accrual travel voucher, please use Defense Travel System (DTS). To file your non-DTS advance or accrual travel voucher, please use eFinance or vMPF, as applicable.

To view your location's specific entitlement refer to the DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 17 Figure 17-1 (Hardship Duty Location Pay Areas).

</78> <79> What is the difference between temporary quarters subsistence expense (TQSE) lump sum (LS) and actual expense (AE)? Unlike TQSE (AE) which covers your actual expenses not to exceed a daily maximum rate, TQSE (LS) is a flat rate computed from the per diem rate of your PDS. Also, TQSE (AE) can be authorized up to 120 days, whereas TQSE (LS) can only be authorized for up to 30 days.
Note for TQSE (AE), PDS locality rate will be used for non-foreign OCONUS localities (ex Guam, Puerto Rico, etc.).

</79> <80> On my Annual Tour, why don't I get an extra travel day if I live outside the commuting area? When official distance from your home to your Annual Tour (AT) is 400 miles or less, one day of travel time is allowed. If you elect to drive your Privately Owned Vehicle (POV) when it is not more advantageous to the government, mileage is limited to one round trip, not to exceed the Transportation Request (TR) cost and one travel day. To file your settlement voucher, please use eFinance.

</81> <82> Can I reduce the amount of my repayment installments on a military pay debt? Yes. As long as your proposed repayment schedule does not extend beyond your date of separation, is over $50.00 per month, and is justified on the grounds of an approved financial hardship, you may have your repayment extended. We suggest you review and complete an AF Form IMT 2451 (Financial Statement - Remission of Indebtedness) prior to visiting your servicing Finance Office to submit your request to extend repayment. Reservists: Your servicing Finance Office may reduce the amount of payment per pay period if the normal collection schedule would cause undue hardship. Please contact your servicing Finance Office for further details concerning indebtedness.

</83> <84> How do I update my Defense Travel System (DTS) profile? It is important for travelers to ensure that Electronic Funds Transfer (EFT), home address, and Government Travel Charge Card (GTCC) information is current in their DTS profile. If this information is not kept up to date, travel reimbursements may be affected. In addition to the information above, travelers should periodically check their profiles in order to update other information such as rank, organization, phone number, emergency contact and other traveler information. You should update your DTS profile: GTCC expires or is reissues Moving/Permanent Change of Station (PCS) Promotion/New Job To update your profile in DTS: From your DTS homepage (after login), mouse over to Traveler Setup on the top menu bar and select Update Personal Profile On the My Profile screen, click on each section to verify your information (My Preferences, My Additional Information, My TSA Information, My Account Information) Save changes, select the Update Personal Information button at the bottom of the screen

</85> <86> If my spouse is a civilian employee, are we both authorized Temporary Lodging Expense (TLE)? You will be authorized TLE and your spouse will be authorized Temporary Quarters Subsistence Expense (TQSE) as long as they cover different expenses. If the TLE and TQSE are covering the same costs, you would not be authorized both payments.

</87> <88> How do I rebut my debt for excess cost of household goods shipment? You are typically notified of your debt by the Finance Office when they receive a DD Form 139 (Pay Authorization) for an excess cost indebtedness. To file for a rebuttal, you must generate a letter stating why you believe the amount that you've been asked to pay is incorrect. You also need to have a copy of the DD Form 139 (obtained from the Finance Office) as well as a copy of your PCS orders. Please submit all required documentation to the Traffic Management Office (TMO) within 30 days of receiving the debt notification. For further information on required documentation please contact TMO. You have 30 days from the date of notification of the Household Goods (HHG) indebtedness to file the rebuttal letter with the Transportation Management Office (TMO). The counselor at TMO will review the letter for completeness and forward it to Joint Personal Property Shipping Office (JPPSO) in San Antonio for a decision. Upon adjudication, JPPSO will notify you of their decision with either an adjusted DD Form 139 increasing/decreasing the debt, or a letter of cancellation of the debt. The TMO will also be notified. It can take several months before you receive notification of indebtedness for exceeding your household weight allowance. This delay is due to carrier billing procedures and the gathering of information by the excess cost adjudication function.

</88> <89> What options do I have for paying back my security deposit advance? You may pay back your security deposit advance over a 12 month period, with minimum monthly payments of $50. If you are overseas and the amount of your security deposit advance is greater than $500, you may defer repayment of the advance until you vacate the quarters for which the advance was taken. This option serves to prevent financial hardship that may be caused by having to pay back a large housing advance payment which will, in all likelihood, be refunded when you move out. Lump sum repayment to the government, of the amount you receive from your landlord upon vacating the quarters, is required. If you receive less than the full amount, taking exchange rate fluctuations into consideration, you may prorate the remaining balance due over up to 12 months. Each payment must be at least $50.

</95> <96> Do I have any other recourse if I am denied a remission or a waiver? For remissions, the Air Force Review Boards Agency (SAF/MRB) will not review a re-submission unless there is additional information that was not initially available or if there is a change in your financial situation. If there is additional information, documentation, or new evidence that was not previously available, it should be submitted to your Finance Office. For waivers, you may appeal the decision. Instructions for doing this are noted in the letter that notifies you of the waiver decision. Additional, you may apply to the Air Force Board for Correction of Military Records through your servicing Personnel Office.
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 69 Figure 69.1 (Notification of an Indebtedness - FSO-Generated Debt) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437231000&usg=AFQjCNHw4VRuHzDI_tJQPttN0dOA__kWow
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 73 Sec 73A 73.5 (Remissions - Special Provisions) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437231000&usg=AFQjCNHw4VRuHzDI_tJQPttN0dOA__kWow
</96> <97> Where do I get my orders for Consecutive Overseas Tour (COT) / In-Place Consecutive Overseas Tour (IPCOT) travel? For COT travel, use your permanent duty travel (PDT) orders issued by the Military Personnel Element (MPE). These orders authorize your COT travel in conjunction with travel from one overseas duty station to another overseas duty station.
For deferred COT travel, your Commander Support Staff (CSS) will publish your orders.
For IPCOT travel, after validation by the Military Personnel Element that you have an approved IPCOT, your leave orders (DD Form 1610 (Request and Authorization for TDY Travel of DoD Personnel) will be published, normally by your CSS
Regulation: AFI 36-3003 Sec G (Unique Leave Provisions) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/production/1/af_a1/publication/afi36-3003/afi36-3003.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437232000&usg=AFQjCNFnisX1ZOzAZ5PMBzIk7VELJqWqSw
Form: DD Form 1610 (Request and Authorization for TDY Travel of DoD Personnel) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.dtic.mil/whs/directives/infomgt/forms/eforms/dd1610.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437232000&usg=AFQjCNEFpRj_1Y5EAMQNPcV4Zv18D9QeOA
</97> <98> How much will my paycheck be as a new Reservist? Your pay is calculated based upon your entitlements which are determined by such factors as rank, years of service, pay date, tax rates, number of dependents, and other factors. To find out about your specific pay, contact your Reserve Pay Office (RPO).
Related links: DFAS Military Pay Tables https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.dfas.mil/militarymembers/payentitlements/militarypaytables.html&sa=D&ust=1558682437232000&usg=AFQjCNGSjbkzhKbxhMGYIXAMR-Ge2FLpzQ
</98> <99> What can I change in myPay? In myPay, you can start, stop or change your voluntary allotments to financial institutions. You can also change your direct deposit, mailing address, withholding for federal and state taxes, and Thrift Savings Plan (TSP). In addition, you can change your personal settings in myPay including your email address, login PIN, login ID and alert settings.
Related Link: myPay https://www.google.com/url?q=https://mypay.dfas.mil/mypay.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437232000&usg=AFQjCNEWEoerl__or4fzvfj0mdWiA88IiA
Related Link: myPay https://www.google.com/url?q=https://mypay.dfas.mil/mypay.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437232000&usg=AFQjCNEWEoerl__or4fzvfj0mdWiA88IiA
Related Link: myPay https://www.google.com/url?q=https://mypay.dfas.mil/mypay.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437232000&usg=AFQjCNEWEoerl__or4fzvfj0mdWiA88IiA
</99> <100> Do I request leave in LeaveWeb? Yes, use Leave Web to request all leaves except leave in conjunction with TDY and PCS. TDY and PCS leaves are processed from your travel voucher. LeaveWeb is an Air Force system that automates requesting and processing leave in lieu of using the hard copy AF IMT 988 (Leave Request/Authorization). LeaveWeb version 4.0 updated the leave system in early 2013. The new version of LeaveWeb: Expands LeaveWeb capabilities to process all 18 types of leave Maintains approved DD 2875 (submitted for special privileges) within the system Requires digital signatures for all requesting and approving levels of military leave Allows all leave to be managed from a central location for system and , allowing all types of leave to be input into LeaveWeb
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 44.9 (LeaveWeb) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437232000&usg=AFQjCNFD3chGju0jh4A3S03py6v4PNooqg
Form: AF IMT 988 (Leave Request/Authorization) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/production/1/saf_fm/form/af988/af988.xfdl&sa=D&ust=1558682437233000&usg=AFQjCNHjfi48t2wMG4Dfqi9siaFRBLuWgw
</100> <101> Does Combat Zone Tax Exemption (CZTE) affect the maximum Thrift Savings Plan (TSP) contribution that I can make? Yes, the CZTE will affect your maximum TSP contribution. If you contribute to TSP from tax-exempt income, your maximum annual contribution is higher than it would be otherwise. For further guidance on maximum contributions, go to the TSP link below.
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 68.10 (Uniformed Services Thrift Savings Plan - Tax Information)) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437233000&usg=AFQjCNFPcyfIk61YfK3sklaFuMBEeym7fQ
Regulation (Reserve Only): AFMAN 65-116 Vol 3 Chap 50 (Reserve Component:) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/production/1/saf_fm/publication/afman65-116v3/afman65-116v3.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437233000&usg=AFQjCNE63r9NtPiyKaQILAr1LZNodB8Qnw
Related Link: TSP limits website https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.tsp.gov/curinfo/qsas-limits.html&sa=D&ust=1558682437233000&usg=AFQjCNFe0p2NMQGYh8iXl4-pC-u5tTVSDg
</101> <102> Upon PCS, when do my overseas allowances stop? Your Overseas Housing Allowance (OHA), Cost of Living Allowance (COLA), and Hardship Duty Pay (HDP), as applicable, will stop effective the day before you depart your OCONUS permanent duty station (PDS).
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 28 Sec 28A 28.3 (COLA - FSO Action) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437233000&usg=AFQjCNFPcyfIk61YfK3sklaFuMBEeym7fQ
Regulation: $JTR_Chap_9_Part_B_Para9105B
Regulation: $JTR_Chap_10_PartEPara10416C
</102> <103> Can I change other leave types to convalescent leave? No, you can not change other leave types to convalescent leave without a written recommendation from a Medical Treatment Facility (MTF) authority or attending physician most familiar with your condition. All convalescent leave must be approved by the unit commander and may not be delegated. You must end one leave period before beginning another.
Regulation: AFI 36-3003 Sec C 6.4 (Convalescent Leave) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/production/1/af_a1/publication/afi36-3003/afi36-3003.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437233000&usg=AFQjCNGxdHV7sJZgpBJHie0dwrMhBhpUcg
</103> <104> How does an increase or decrease in my pay affect my taxes? Generally, any increase in your basic pay or any taxable entitlement, such as hardship duty pay or CONUS COLA, will increase your federal and state income tax withholding. A decrease in taxable pay will reduce your federal and state income tax withholding. In addition, your basic pay is taxed at 6.2% for social security and 1.45% for Medicare. Basic pay is your only item of compensation that is subject to tax for social security and Medicare.
noref
noref
</104> <105> As a Reservist, how many days of leave can I take? You are authorized to take the total amount of leave you have accrued. Your commander may also grant advance leave, which is the amount of leave you will accrue through the end of your active duty tour. Leave days must be taken by the last day of your tour. If you have taken advance leave and your tour is cut short, the number of days you did not accrue will become excess leave and must be collected from your pay and allowances.
Regulation: AFI 36-3003 Sec B 4.0 (Managing the Leave Program) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/production/1/af_a1/publication/afi36-3003/afi36-3003.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437234000&usg=AFQjCNEr0uOlaO19Vrbdyktyo_p53XzK9g
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 3 Chap 29.1.6 (Reserve Component: Use of Leave) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/production/1/saf_fm/publication/afman65-116v3/afman65-116v3.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437234000&usg=AFQjCNHLt3Yg0s3D755hJdZkeUs1XPyV0Q
</105> <106> Why did my tax withholding change after my promotion/demotion? Simply stated, your promotion or demotion results in a change in your taxable income which affects your withholding for taxes. If you are participating in the thrift savings plan (TSP) your contribution will also change as a result of your promotion or demotion. If, after reviewing your leave and earnings statement (LES), you still have questions about your pay as a result of your promotion or demotion, contact your servicing Finance Office.
noref
noref
</106> <107> What cost am I limited to for transportation on Renewal Agreement Travel (RAT)? Department of Defense policy requires that you use an available commercial travel office (CTO) or travel management center (TMC) to arrange your official travel, including RAT. If you do not use an available CTO/TMC, your reimbursement is limited to the cost that the government would have paid if a CTO/TMC had made the arrangements. If a CTO/TMC is not available to arrange your transportation, your reimbursement is limited to the least expensive, unrestricted economy/coach fare that would have met the mission requirement.
Regulation: JTR Chap 2 Part F Para 2400 (CTO Use) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/travelreg.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437234000&usg=AFQjCNGnOXth_7MciZxsaMzT8RFa77TXFA
</107> <108> Why is there a Hostile Fire Pay/Imminent Danger Pay (HFP/IDP) debt on my account? A HFP/IDP debt is generated on your Leave and Earnings Statement (LES) if the entitlement is not stopped in a timely manner, which results in an overpayment. After you file your final travel voucher and a transaction is processed to stop the HFP/IDP, it is backdated to the day you were no longer entitled to HFP/IDP and this may create a debt.
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 69.20 (Indebtedness - Appeal) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437235000&usg=AFQjCNF_QQpsZgEpRsW0hbT2Ruq77bEj8w
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 10 Para 1001 (Special Pay - Entitlement Provisions) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437235000&usg=AFQjCNFj_R853oqz8NwqiXkmgCJU_KZTEA
</108> <109> What Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH) rate do I receive when I PCS from OCONUS to CONUS? Typically, while in PCS status returning from an OCONUS duty location, you will receive BAH Transit (BAH-T). This rate will start the day you depart your OCONUS duty station and will continue until the day before you report to your new PDS. For example, if you depart your OCONUS duty station on Saturday and report to your new PDS on Thursday, then you will receive BAH-T from Saturday through Wednesday.
If you were on an unaccompanied tour, then generally you will continue to receive the BAH rate based on the location of your dependents until the day before you arrive at your new PDS. For current BAH-T rates go to Per Diem Rates
Regulation: $JTR_Chap_10_PartEPara10416C
Related Link: Per Diem Rates https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/perdiemCalc.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437235000&usg=AFQjCNED2aODrnE54wXUlqAmNOaHuUhlcw
</109> <110> If I stop my Thrift Savings Plan (TSP) contribution, can I restart them at any time? Yes, your TSP contributions can be restarted by going to the myPay link below. For additional information, please go to the Thrift Savings Plan Website below or call a TSP representative at 1-TSP-YOU-FRST (1-877-968-3778).
Related Link: myPay https://www.google.com/url?q=https://mypay.dfas.mil/mypay.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437235000&usg=AFQjCNF6mjt5rcEMx-Nb9wwyD3ePFdR9Cg
Related Link: Thrift Savings Plan Website https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.tsp.gov/&sa=D&ust=1558682437236000&usg=AFQjCNHmSWJwF46EnuRm5ZTXO9aMUAjeXA
</110> <111> According to my TDY orders, I am authorized civilian clothing allowance. Why didn't I receive it? If you have not already done so, you'll need to take a copy of your TDY orders authorizing civilian clothing allowance to your servicing Finance Office for posting to your paycheck. If you have already taken your TDY orders to your servicing Finance Office, please contact your servicing Finance Office to inquire on the status of your payment. For officers to be entitled to civilian clothing allowance, your permanent duty station (PDS) must be OCONUS, regardless of your TDY location. Reservists: Civilian clothing allowance is only authorized if you are on active duty for more than 6 months.
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 33 Sec 33A 33.6.2 (Enlisted Members' Civilian Clothing Allowance - Substantiating Documents) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437236000&usg=AFQjCNG8FTTvwwVqh9laXjsWC5YWrN_Szg
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 33 Sec 33B 33.10 (Civilian Clothing Allowance for Officers - Substantiating Documents) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437236000&usg=AFQjCNG8FTTvwwVqh9laXjsWC5YWrN_Szg
Regulation (Reserve Only): AFMAN 65-116 Vol 3 Chap 15.4 (Reserve Component: Civilian Clothing) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/production/1/saf_fm/publication/afman65-116v3/afman65-116v3.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437236000&usg=AFQjCNERCdH8qGFLeaOKJEGbLUJDVHzGUQ
</111> <112> What entitlements am I eligible to receive when on an Active Duty tour for 29 days or less? As a Reservist on an Active Duty tour for 29 days or less, you are entitled to: Basic Pay Basic Allowance for Housing-Reserve Component (BAH-RC) unless on a Contingency Order then Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH) Basic Allowance for Subsistence (BAS) The following entitlements may also apply if authorized on your orders: Special Pays Hostile Fire Pay/Imminent Danger Pay (HFP/IDP) Combat Zone Tax Exclusion (CZTE) Cost of Living Allowance (COLA) Overseas Housing Allowance (OHA) Details on the entitlements listed here can be found in the regulations below.
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 3 (Defense Joint Military Pay System - Reserve Component - DJMS-RC) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/production/1/saf_fm/publication/afman65-116v3/afman65-116v3.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437236000&usg=AFQjCNERCdH8qGFLeaOKJEGbLUJDVHzGUQ
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A (Military Pay Policy and Procedures - Active Duty and Reserve Pay) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437237000&usg=AFQjCNEkUZujH7OylCRLanlQ4m4jJ-3Q5g
</112> <113> If I return voluntarily to my PDS, how does this affect my Family Separation Allowance TDY (FSA-T)? Your FSA-T entitlement will continue during short visits to your PDS as long as you do not perform duty at your home station. For example, if you take a weekend visits to your PDS, then your FSA-T will continue.
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 27 Para 270304A5 (FSA Computation - Interrupted TDY Status) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437237000&usg=AFQjCNEkUZujH7OylCRLanlQ4m4jJ-3Q5g
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 27 Para 270304A5 (FSA Computation - Interrupted TDY Status) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437237000&usg=AFQjCNEkUZujH7OylCRLanlQ4m4jJ-3Q5g
</113> <114> If my household goods (HHG) rebuttal was denied, do I have any other recourse? Yes, you may: Resubmit your rebuttal, only if you have new information not included in the original rebuttal, File for a remission of the debt through your servicing Finance Office, Apply to the Air Force Board for Correction of Military Records (BMCR) through your servicing Personnel Office to have your records corrected or eliminate an error or injustice, or Request relief from the DoD, Office of Hearings and Appeals (DOHA) through your servicing Finance Office
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 70 Sec 70A 70.8 (Rebuttal of Excess Cost) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437237000&usg=AFQjCNF3c4YdM0NhZM3gRQisavKhAU5FJA
Regulation: DOD HHG Portal General Excess Cost Questions https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.move.mil/documents/DOD/FAQs_-_Excess_Cost_Evaluation_and_Rebuttal.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437237000&usg=AFQjCNFhvyKuxbXZ__xiXYPChzwoMZXvbA
</114> <115> Can Officers receive a maternity clothing allowance? No. Officers cannot receive a maternity clothing allowance.
Regulation: AFI 36-3014 Chap 2 Para 2.1.5 (Supplemental Clothing Allowance) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/production/1/af_a1/publication/afi36-3014/afi36-3014.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437237000&usg=AFQjCNFSwW29GD_HYg3s2VPDfUq4CR8FIA
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 29 Para 290402 (Supplementary Clothing Allowances) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437238000&usg=AFQjCNExCF8uaSvqwbtJ9Dbh9JQM9xn6yg
</115> <116> Am I entitled to receive the officer uniform allowance when on an active duty tour for less than 30 days? You are not entitled to receive the officer uniform allowance when on active duty for less than 30 days. As a reservist, you are entitled to one initial uniform allowance for any of the following: Upon first reporting for active duty (other than for training) for a period of more than 90 days Upon completion of at least 14 days of active duty or active duty for training Upon completion of 14 inactive duty periods, provided each period is at least 2 hours duration Upon reporting for the first period of active duty required of a member of the Armed Forces Health Professions Scholarship Program The initial Officer uniform allowance is $400.
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 30 Para 300201 (Initial Uniform Allowance - General) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437238000&usg=AFQjCNExCF8uaSvqwbtJ9Dbh9JQM9xn6yg
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 30 Para 300301 (Additional Active Duty Uniform Allowance - General) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437238000&usg=AFQjCNExCF8uaSvqwbtJ9Dbh9JQM9xn6yg
</116> <117> How do I get a Government Travel Charge Card (GTCC)? Contact your unit's Agency Program Coordinator (APC) who will assist you with submitting an application for a GTCC. Your unit APC is also responsible for maintaining all accounts for your unit. If you do not know who your APC is, check with your command section.
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 9 Chap 3 Para 0309 (Applying for a GTCC) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437238000&usg=AFQjCNExCF8uaSvqwbtJ9Dbh9JQM9xn6yg
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 9 Chap 3 Para 0309 (Applying for a GTCC) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437238000&usg=AFQjCNExCF8uaSvqwbtJ9Dbh9JQM9xn6yg
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 9 Chap 3 Para 0309 (Applying for a GTCC) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437238000&usg=AFQjCNExCF8uaSvqwbtJ9Dbh9JQM9xn6yg
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 9 Chap 3 Para 0309 (Applying for a GTCC) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437239000&usg=AFQjCNGwNd0QVITn8e6lL1daStiodDNKKQ
</117> <118> How does the TRICARE Dental Program allotment work? The TRICARE Active Duty Dental Program is a voluntary, premium-based dental insurance plan administered by MetLife. Once you enroll in the TRICARE Dental Program, monthly premiums are deducted from your pay account via allotment. Enrollment is not automatic. Visit TRICARE Dental Program for online application and additional information.
Contact MetLife for questions or concerns with your TRICARE Dental allotment by visiting the TRICARE Dental Program. Alternatively, you may also visit your nearest TRICARE service center for assistance.
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 61 (Tricare - Family Member Dental Plan - Tricare - FMDP) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437239000&usg=AFQjCNEBHR8FXy6VGjaLycAbCEiupi1vcg
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 54 (Tricare Dental Program - TDP) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437239000&usg=AFQjCNGwNd0QVITn8e6lL1daStiodDNKKQ
Related Link: TRICARE Dental Program https://www.google.com/url?q=http://mybenefits.metlife.com/tricare&sa=D&ust=1558682437239000&usg=AFQjCNFXGbUvSbL8rmAL_zb9NdFSetd0aA
</118> <119> Why do I have to pay the balance on my Government Travel Charge Card (GTCC)? As a GTCC account holder, you are obligated to pay all undisputed amounts in the bills that you receive from the card issuer. Your account is considered delinquent if unpaid 60 days after the billing date. If you have a charge that you dispute, contact your unit APC who will guide you in filing a notice of dispute with the card issuer.
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 9 Chap 3 Para 031202 (Responsibilities of Travelers for Payments) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437239000&usg=AFQjCNGwNd0QVITn8e6lL1daStiodDNKKQ
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 9 Chap 3 Para 031202 (Responsibilities of Travelers for Payments) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437239000&usg=AFQjCNGwNd0QVITn8e6lL1daStiodDNKKQ
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 9 Chap 3 Para 031202 (Responsibilities of Travelers for Payments) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437239000&usg=AFQjCNGwNd0QVITn8e6lL1daStiodDNKKQ
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 9 Chap 3 Para 031202 (Responsibilities of Travelers for Payments) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437239000&usg=AFQjCNGwNd0QVITn8e6lL1daStiodDNKKQ
</119> <120> Can I receive Hazardous Duty Incentive Pay (HDIP) in conjunction with other incentive pays? Yes, you may receive a maximum of two incentive pays concurrently.
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 21.2 (Incentive Pays - Entitlement to ACIP, HDIP, and Other Hazardous Duty Incentive Pays) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437240000&usg=AFQjCNGCfqtA_40ieItnQOkoS9gjmCNEgg
Regulation (Reserve Only): AFMAN 65-116 Vol 3 Chap 20.2 (Reserve Component: Incentive Pay and Dual Incentive Pay Processing) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/production/1/saf_fm/publication/afman65-116v3/afman65-116v3.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437240000&usg=AFQjCNGoF-frKHXZdFUkrw-hvuarORiXXQ
</120> <121> How do I change my Thrift Savings Plan (TSP) allocations? To change the allocation of your contributions between TSP funds, use the Thrift Savings Plan Website. To change your withholding for TSP, please use myPay. Civilian Employees: Civilian employees can change their TSP election in the Employee Benefits Information System (EBIS). EBIS can be accessed via the AFPC Secure Apps page. Note: If you have issues logging into EBIS, complete the following steps. 1.) Open Internet Explorer. 2.) Access Tools > Internet Options > Advanced and scroll down to the Security category. Ensure the checkboxes next to "Use SSL 2.0, Use SSL 3.0, and Use TLS 1.0" are all checked. 3.) If you check any of the boxes, be sure to also click on the Content tab and clear the SSL state.

</121> <122> Do I have to take leave if I am outside of my local area on a non-duty day? No, you do not have to take leave outside the local area, unless you are away from your place of duty on a normal duty day. Non-duty days are considered regular pass periods and your commander cannot impose mileage restrictions, provided you are available for duty your next scheduled duty day. However, unit commanders may require members to be able to return to duty within a reasonable time in the event of an operational mission requirement such as a recall, unit alert, or unit emergency. The local area is the place where you live and commute to your workplace.

</123> <124> Which Thrift Savings Plan (TSP) funds should I contribute to? By default, all customers' initial TSP contributions are invested in the "G" fund. However, you may elect to contribute to any of the options that TSP offers. It is at your discretion which of the funds you should contribute to. It is also your responsibility select or change your contribution allocations by visiting My Account: Contribution Allocations (You will need your account number or user ID and your 4-digit Personal Identification Number). You can also call the Thriftline at 1-TSP-YOU-FRST (1-877-968-3778) or at TDD (1-877-847-4385) for the hearing-impared. For further information on the funds available, go to the Thrift Savings Plan Website.

</124> <125> Can I split up the 12 We Are All Recruiters (WEAR) leave days as I choose? You will coordinate your 12 WEAR leave days with the recruiting squadron you are assigned to.

</125> <126> I missed the military aircraft, can I get a ticket home from my Inactive Duty Training (IDT)/Unit Training Assembly (UTA)? You are not authorized travel and transportation allowances for any IDT/UTA training in the city or town that the unit headquarters or the unit assignment is located. This includes travel between home and unit, attendance at weekly drills, or duty in lieu of weekly drills.
If you are directed to a location other than the assigned Unit or headquarters, then you are authorized IDT/UTA pay for one or more days as applicable.

</126> <127> Can I contribute more than $100 per month towards the Montgomery GI Bill (MGIB)? No. Your $100 monthly contribution amount is set by law. Once enrolled, you must contribute $1,200 total, with a monthly deduction of $100. You also have the option of contributing up to an additional $600 Kicker for a maximum contribution of $1,800 total. If you have more questions about how to contribute contact your servicing Finance Office. If you have any other questions pertaining to MGIB or Kicker refunds, benefits or eligibility you will need to contact your education office.

</127> <128> When will I be paid for my Inactive Duty Training (IDT)/Unit Training Assembly (UTA)? The Finance Office performs runs for pay eight times a month (usually Tuesdays and Thursdays). These runs will generate a pay date approximately eight days after the run date. Each run includes manual inputs as well as Unit Training Processing System (UTAPS) transactions.
noref
</128> <129> Where do I submit my House Hunting allowance claim? All claims for house hunting must be submitted to the Finance Office servicing your permanent duty station.

</129> <130> How do I request an emergency payment? If you need an emergency military pay payment, upon approval from your commander or first sergeant you need to submit your signed letter authorizing issuance of payment to your servicing Finance Office. The amount may not exceed your accrued pay and allowances to date less normal statutory deductions.
If you need emergency payment for travel, you will need to have a copy of your travel orders stating you do not have a Government Travel Charge Card (GTCC) or GTCC use is restricted. Take a copy of your orders to your servicing Finance Office for assistance. If you are not at your home station, please contact the Finance Office of your losing permanent duty station for further guidance on requesting an emergency travel payment.

</131> <132> Can I get my Dislocation Allowance (DLA) in advance? You are required to use your Government Travel Charge Card (GTCC) to the greatest extent possible for all PCS related expenses. This includes expenses which are linked to the DLA.
If the GTCC cannot be used to pay the expense directly, you should attempt to obtain the necessary funds from an ATM. If the ATM limits prevent obtaining enough cash, a bank teller can provide the advance if the card is presented. If none of the above methods to obtain the funds are prudent, the Finance Office can pay the DLA in advance by EFT to your account.
If you are exempt from GTCC use, you may receive DLA in advance. Advance DLA will not be paid earlier than 10 days prior to departure.
To file a claim for DLA, please use eFinance. For Reservists, your orders must state that PCS entitlements are authorized.
