</514> <515> Will I receive Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH) if I'm in government housing and my dependents are still residing at my last PDS? No. The statutory purpose of BAH is to partially offset the cost of private housing when family type government quarters are not furnished. Once you accept family government quarters, except privatized quarters, the allowance to BAH no longer exists.
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 26.2.2 (Basic Allowance for Housing-I (BAH-I)) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437417000&usg=AFQjCNGAGFf3jFQAAAENTGvgv8X-gnaOQA
Regulation: $JTR_Chap_10_Part_D_Para_10300
</515> <516> How much will I receive for picking up or dropping off my Privately Owned Vehicle (POV)? Uniformed Members: If your delivery or pick up is separate from your PCS travel, you are authorized round trip POV mileage reimbursement to the Vehicle Processing Center (VPC) at the TDY rate of $0.575 per mile.
To file your POV travel voucher, please use eFinance. If you deliver or pick up your POV in conjunction with PCS travel, you will be paid at the same rate as all other POV travel during the PCS. The rate is $123 per day for lodging and meals and $0.23 per mile.
To file your PCS settlement travel voucher, please use PCS In-Processing System (PIPS) (PIPS). Civilian Employees: If the POV pick up or drop off is concurrent with a Permanent Duty Travel (PDT), then you receive the $0.23 per mile, plus applicable per diem. If it is not concurrent with PDT, then you receive the applicable $0.23 per mile for one way travel for the official distance traveled.
To file your POV travel voucher, please use eFinance.
Regulation: $JTR_Chap_5_Part_A_Para5354
Regulation: $JTR_Chap_5_Part_B_Para_5726
Related Link: eFinance https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.my.af.mil/efinanceprod&sa=D&ust=1558682437417000&usg=AFQjCNE8odvQwghndXpp4MossDT7aStlDw
Related Link: Mileage Rates https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/otherratesMile.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437417000&usg=AFQjCNGYuWwuasfXNvJ1v4r6KHIOhSZ0CA
Related Link: PCS In-Processing System (PIPS) https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.my.af.mil/efinanceprod&sa=D&ust=1558682437417000&usg=AFQjCNE8odvQwghndXpp4MossDT7aStlDw
</516> <517> How many days am I authorized for Temporary Lodging Expense (TLE) when I PCS? The number of days authorized for TLE when you PCS is based on where you're PCS'ing to and from: OCONUS to CONUS (Overseas to Stateside): authorized 10 days at the new stateside base after arrival. CONUS to OCONUS (Stateside to Overseas): authorized 5 days stateside at the old stateside PDS, prior to departure. CONUS to CONUS (Stateside to Stateside): authorized 10 days (combined) at either stateside location. OCONUS to OCONUS (Overseas to Overseas): TLE is a stateside allowance and not payable while lodging overseas. Temporary Lodging Allowance (TLA) is payable instead. If the number of days you actually occupy temporary lodging is less than what you are authorized, you will only be reimbursed for the actual days in lodging. TLE is not authorized in conjunction with separation or retirement from active duty.
Regulation: JTR Chap 5 Part A Para 5434 (Uniformed Members - Temporary Lodging - CONUS Temporary Lodging Expense - TLE) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/travelreg.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437418000&usg=AFQjCNESkYmzHiC72GQWWUMhonSCADK14g
Regulation: JTR Chap 5 Part A Para 5434 (Uniformed Members - Temporary Lodging - CONUS Temporary Lodging Expense - TLE) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/travelreg.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437418000&usg=AFQjCNESkYmzHiC72GQWWUMhonSCADK14g
</517> <518> If I drive to my new PDS, how many travel days do I receive? If you are traveling to a new PDS entirely by means of your Privately Owned Vehicle (POV), then you are authorized one day of official travel time for every 350 official miles as determined by the Defense Table of Official Distance. If the excess distance is 1 or more miles after dividing the total number miles by 350, one additional day of travel time is authorized. If the official mileage from your old PDS to your new PDS is 350 miles or fewer, then only one travel day is allowed.
Regulation: JTR Chap 3 Part A Para 3025 (Travel-Transportation Policy - Travel Time) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/travelreg.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437418000&usg=AFQjCNESkYmzHiC72GQWWUMhonSCADK14g
Regulation: JTR Chap 3 Part A Para 3025 (Travel-Transportation Policy - Travel Time) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/travelreg.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437418000&usg=AFQjCNESkYmzHiC72GQWWUMhonSCADK14g
</518> <519> Can I be reimbursed for ATM fees and Government Travel Charge Card (GTCC) card advance fees? No, as of 1 October 2014, administrative fees for ATM use during official travel are covered in the Incidental Expense (IE) portion of per diem and are not reimbursable. Government Travel Charge Card (GTCC) advance fees are also considered to be covered by your IE portion of per diem. GTCC late payment, expedited delivery, and Chin/PIN care issue fees are covered, per JTR Appendix G (Reimbursable and Non-Reimbursable Official Travel Expenses). Additionally, merchant surcharge fees are also reimbursable. Some merchants (typically overseas) will include a surcharge fee when you use your GTCC.
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 9 Chap 3 Para 030305 (Automated Teller Machine (ATM) Use https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437418000&usg=AFQjCNHxJ7gQgNI39bWvjkydAQF-X7oV9A
Regulation: JTR Appendix G (Reimbursable and Non-Reimbursable Official Travel Expenses) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/travelreg.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437419000&usg=AFQjCNHC-XGVClcAXit9ZrIbexVzMdCMYA
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 9 Chap 3 Para 031202D6 (Cash Advance (ATM Withdrawal) Fee) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437419000&usg=AFQjCNGve3YokelL-rOlfGyYGhJVRU6Ezw
</519> <520> What modes of transportation can I take for Renewal Agreement Travel (RAT)? When you take RAT, you are authorized transportation from the OCONUS permanent duty station to your residence at the time you were assigned to your OCONUS permanent duty station, including transportation to and from common carrier terminals. You must contact your installation's commercial travel office to arrange your transportation.
Regulation: JTR Chap 7 Part A Para 7065 (Civilian Employees Only - Renewal Agreement Travel - RAT) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/travelreg.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437419000&usg=AFQjCNHC-XGVClcAXit9ZrIbexVzMdCMYA
</520> <521> Do I have to take terminal leave in conjunction with separation or retirement? No, any unused leave will be sold at the time of your separation or retirement, provided: Your discharge is under honorable conditions, and The total amount of leave sold during your military career does not exceed 60 days (including the potential leave to be sold in conjunction with separation/retirement) If you are ineligible for leave sell back, any leave that remains unused at the time of your separation or retirement will be lost.
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 35 Para 350101 (Separation Payments - Accrued Leave Pay - General Entitlement) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437419000&usg=AFQjCNGve3YokelL-rOlfGyYGhJVRU6Ezw
</521> <522> If I PCS to an accompanied location (CONUS or OCONUS), but my dependents don't move with me, am I still authorized Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH) at my old PDS rate? Normally, no. Your BAH is based on your permanent duty station (PDS) location. However, there are circumstances where you may be authorized to receive a BAH at the old PDS rate. Examples of these circumstances include: You are assigned to a PDS in an area in which sufficient housing quantities do not exist You are assigned to indeterminate Temporary Duty (TDY), or TDY pending further orders You are assigned to a Professional Military Education (PME) or a training course that is scheduled for the duration of one year or less. In order to receive a BAH rate, other than the PDS location, you must apply through your local Military Personnel Flight.
You may receive BAH based on your old station rate in situations where you are making a PCS move to an overseas location where your dependents are restricted, and your dependents are residing separately from you. If your dependents relocate to a designated place, the BAH rate will be based on that location. To make changes to your BAH, please use eFinance.
Regulation: $JTR_Chap_10PartEPara10402B
Regulation: $JTR_Chap_10_PartEPara10408
Regulation: $JTR_Chap_10_PartEPara10412
Regulation: $JTRCh10PartEPar10406BTab10E4
Related Link: eFinance https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.my.af.mil/efinanceprod&sa=D&ust=1558682437420000&usg=AFQjCNHFJrmljMKfkIoWo_6WWqVRi2-4FA
</522> <523> How long does the household goods (HHG) rebuttal process take? Please contact the Traffic Management Office (TMO) for information on the rebuttal process timeline.
noref
noref
</523> <524> What rate of Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH) / Overseas Housing Allowance (OHA) will I receive if my dependents remain in the area of my old PDS when I PCS to an unaccompanied OCONUS location? Provided your dependents remain at your old permanent duty station (PDS), you will receive the BAH/OHA rate of your old PDS, unless your dependents occupy family government quarters.
For current rates, see BAH Rates To make changes to your BAH/OHA, please use eFinance. Reservists: To make changes to your BAH/OHA, please contact your servicing Finance Office.
Regulation: $JTR_Chap_10PartEPara10402B2
Related Link: BAH Rates https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/bahCalc.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437420000&usg=AFQjCNEQDwHNhNaYsnDxGGj9mB6S_ERIfg

</524> <525> Am I eligible for Family Separation Allowance TDY (FSA-T)? To be eligible for FSA-T you must have dependents, or be married Military to Military and living together, and perform TDY away from your PDS for a continuous period of more than 30 days. Additionally, your dependents must not reside at or near your TDY location nor visit for more than 30 days. See the link below for further details.
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 27 Para 270103 (Entitlement Provisions - Family Separation Allowance) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437420000&usg=AFQjCNFXQ1nfMjcoMnCbP5_dkLz8JeHYlQ
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 27 Para 270103 (Entitlement Provisions - Family Separation Allowance) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437420000&usg=AFQjCNFXQ1nfMjcoMnCbP5_dkLz8JeHYlQ
</525> <526> Which areas are entitled to participate in the Savings Deposit Program (SDP)? The countries of Iraq and Afghanistan are two of the designated areas where members can participate in the SDP. However, the current list of designated areas include many more areas in addition to those two countries. Please go to the link below for the current list of areas designated for participation in the SDP.
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 51 Para 510101 (Savings Deposit Program - SDP - Definitions) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437421000&usg=AFQjCNGTAvhFCSAsPMVqWjfCF6_FaXMnNw

</526> <527> How do I stop the Hostile Fire Pay/Imminent Danger Pay (HFP/IDP) I've been receiving while I was deployed? HFP/IDP is stopped when you file your final settlement travel voucher. If you have noticed that the entitlement has not stopped, and you have received payment for your travel voucher, please contact your local Finance Office. This entitlement may also be stopped by your deployed location Finance Office. Hostile fire pay is payable for the entire month in which you accrued the entitlement. However, imminent danger pay is prorated daily and paid based on the number of days you performed duty in the designated area. To file your travel settlement voucher, please use Defense Travel System (DTS) or eFinance, as applicable. Reservists - HFP/IDP is stopped when you submit a copy of your final settlement travel voucher to your servicing Finance Office upon return from TDY.
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 13.3.2 (IDP can be reported on an AF Form 1881 or...) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437421000&usg=AFQjCNGxiJBpGRW37aPe2YYHeV3czVl3jw
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 3 Chap 21 (Reserve Component: Special Pay - Foreign Duty Pay (FDP), Hostile Fire/Imminent Danger Pay (HF/IDP), Foreign Language Proficiency Pay (FLPP)) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/production/1/saf_fm/publication/afman65-116v3/afman65-116v3.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437421000&usg=AFQjCNEIbqnTqkt0H8tqPpQm_ko3oHUy2Q

</527> <528> Do I claim the accruals that I received while I was gone as an advance on my travel voucher? Yes, claim all accruals you received during the duration of your TDY, by annotating them on your final travel voucher after your return. This is not applicable to reservists who've received partial settlements. Your final settlement voucher will only cover the time from your last partial to the return to PDS and you do not need to show all previous partials. To file your non-DTS travel voucher, please use eFinance.
Regulation: AFI 65-114 Chap 8 Sec 8A 8.6.6.1 (Advances/Prior Payments) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/production/1/saf_fm/publication/afi65-114/afi65-114.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437422000&usg=AFQjCNEfn9oZkvd_iiz3gDVC9NI3eSAwpw

Regulation: AFI 65-114 Chap 9.4.7 (Accrual Payments for TDYs over 45 days) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/production/1/saf_fm/publication/afi65-114/afi65-114.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437422000&usg=AFQjCNEfn9oZkvd_iiz3gDVC9NI3eSAwpw
</528> <529> How do I contribute, and how much can I contribute, to the Savings Deposit Program (SDP)? You can make contributions at your deployed location by cash or check. In addition, active duty members can make deposits by allotment. Your deployed Finance Office will be able to assist with cash deposits or allotments to SDP. The maximum that you can contribute to SDP at one time is your un-allotted pay and allowances. Your un-allotted pay and allowances is the amount of money you are entitled to receive on payday minus your authorized deductions and allotments. Pay and allowances include special continuation pay, reenlistment bonuses, travel allowance on discharge and pay for unused accrued leave. You may combine pay accrued from one payday with pay accrued from the following payday to make one deposit as long as that deposit does not exceed what you are entitled to be paid for a one month period. NOTE: Although there is no limit on the amount you can contribute to SDP, only amounts up to $10,000 will accrue interest at a rate of 10 percent per year.
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 51 Para 510101C (Savings Deposit Program - SDP - Unallotted Current Pay and Allowances) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437423000&usg=AFQjCNFces4zq6f2xTFogeiN4SRWIvRlig
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 51 Para 5103 (Limitations on Amounts of Deposits) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437423000&usg=AFQjCNFces4zq6f2xTFogeiN4SRWIvRlig

</529> <530> My household goods (HHG) rebuttal was denied, can I re-file since I now have new information? Yes. If you have new information that was not previously submitted you may re-file your rebuttal. Financial hardship may not be used as a reason for re-submission. Contact the Traffic Management Office (TMO) for additional information on the rebuttal process.
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 70 Sec 70A 70.8 (Rebuttal of Excess Cost) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437423000&usg=AFQjCNGGT8qEd5bdAEwGh7ZeaPtrFLWzMg
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 70 Sec 70A 70.8 (Rebuttal of Excess Cost) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437424000&usg=AFQjCNGSnwpinfZwi48qwZPJA6OiMTAWPw
</530> <531> If my household goods (HHG) rebuttal request is denied, when will collection begin? Normally, your debt collection will start the next available pay period after notification of the rebuttal decision.
noref
noref
</531> <532> How do I start or stop an allotment? For active duty members, you can start, stop and change allotments to financial institutions using the myPay web site. Allotments to pay for insurance premiums, privatized housing rent, and home mortgage payments can be started, stopped and changed using the eFinance application. If your allotment can't be processed on myPay or eFinance, you can complete a DD Form 2558 (Authorization to Start Stop or Change an Allotment) and submit it to your servicing Finance Office for processing.
Civilian employees can also start, stop or change allotments to financial institutions using the myPay web site. For all other allotment processing such as charity, union dues, or insurance, employees need to contact their local customer service representative (CSR). You can visit the myPay web site to change, stop, and start an allotment.
Active duty members and civilian employees who want to purchase savings bonds by payroll deduction need to first establish an account at Treasury Direct Website. After you establish your account, you will need your account number and the Treasury Direct routing number to start an allotment via myPay to Treasury Direct for purchasing your bonds.

</532> <533> What happens to the half day of accrued leave I do not take as terminal leave? If you have a half day balance of accrued leave at the time of separation or retirement it will be sold/paid in your final separation payment. However, if you have already sold 60 days of leave during your military career the half day of leave will be lost.
Regulation: AFI 36-3003 Sec C 6.7.5.7 (Terminal Leave - Cannot use half-days) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/production/1/af_a1/publication/afi36-3003/afi36-3003.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437425000&usg=AFQjCNESSfO17SHgvtdHDgPgAH-NuXn0nA

</533> <534> How long do I have to be TDY before I can request an accrual? You need to be on TDY for at least 45 days before you can submit for an accrual. Your first accrual is payable 30 days from the first day of the TDY, and can be paid every 30 days thereafter until you return to your PDS. If you have significant travel expenses to get to your TDY point, then the day 30 day rule for the first accrual may be waived for an immediate payment to your Government Travel Charge Card (GTCC). To file your accrual travel voucher, please use Defense Travel System (DTS).
To file your non-DTS accrual travel voucher, please use eFinance or vMPF, as applicable.

</534> <535> What is the current rate of civilian clothing allowance? Civilian clothing allowance rates are subject to annual adjustments. NOTE: An officer is only entitled to a civilian clothing allowance when his/her permanent duty station (PDS) is outside the United States. </535> <536> How will I be notified of the household goods (HHG) rebuttal decision? You will be notified via letter from the Joint Personal Property Shipping Office (JPPSO) / Excess Cost Adjudication Function (ECAF).

</536> <537> Am I entitled to a Civilian Clothing Allowance? If you are required to wear civilian clothing more than half the time while performing official duties, you may be entitled to a Civilian Clothing Allowance. The authorization will come from published orders that state that you are required to wear civilian clothing. Officers are entitled to Civilian Clothing Allowance only if their permanent duty station is located outside the United States. Entitlement information can be obtained in the DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 29 Para 290403 (Civilian Clothing Allowances for Officers and Enlisted), and current rates can be found in DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 29 Table 29-8 (Civilian Clothing Allowances for Officer and Enlisted Members).

</537> <538> What avenues can I use to get my accrual processed? You may start the accrual payment process prior to departure by visiting your servicing Finance Office. Simply fill out the accrual form and submit it with a copy of your orders.
If you did not set up the accruals before departing TDY, you can either use eFinance or vMPF to request your accrual.
If you do not have access to the AF Portal you can visit the Finance Office at your TDY or deployed location and they will assist you in preparing the proper documentation to be submitted to the AFFSC for processing.
If there is no Finance Office where you're TDY, you will need to reach back to your home station Finance Office for assistance.

</538> <539> What do I need to start my Hostile Fire Pay/Imminent Danger Pay (HFP/IDP)? Hostile Fire Pay/Imminent Danger Pay (HFP/IDP) entitlements are started by the deployed Finance Office once you in-process at your deployed location. If you have already in-processed and you are not receiving HFP/IDP, you will need to notify the deployed Finance Office. The only documentation required is a copy of your orders.
Depending on the date you in-process, you may not see the entitlement reflected in your pay until the following month. However, the entitlement is retroactive to your arrival. For imminent danger pay, the entitlement will be prorated based on your date of arrival in the designated area. Hostile fire pay is paid for the entire month in which you earned it, without proration. Reservists - You need to provide your servicing Finance Office a copy of your orders directing you to the qualifying area and your projected date in country.

</539> <540> How do I receive my Civilian Clothing Allowance? Active Duty: If you qualify for a civilian clothing allowance, you must submit one of the following to your Finance Office to process the entitlement: Assignment/reassignment orders (PCS) TDY orders A letter from your commander Your Finance Office will submit the documentation to the AFFSC for processing and payment should flow into your next available paycheck. Reserve: You are not authorized civilian clothing allowance unless you are on active duty for more than 6 months. If you are on active duty for more than 6 months and are qualified for a civilian clothing allowance, submit the following to your Finance Office: Orders An official letter from the appropriate competent authority A letter from your MPF stating the dollar amount authorized Once these documents are submitted to your Finance Office, they will process the entitlement and it will flow to your next available paycheck.

</540> <541> Is it cheaper to fly or drive for my TDY or PCS? TDY: Your orders approving official (AO) will determine if driving your Privately Owned Vehicle (POV) is advantageous to the government or not. If your orders approving official authorizes you to drive, then you will be authorized mileage, tolls, ferry fees, and per diem for driving. If your orders are not advantageous to the government, you will be reimbursed for your actual method of travel, not to exceed the constructed cost of government procured common carrier transportation (i.e. commercial air). The current mileage rate for using your POV on a TDY is $0.575 per mile. PCS: Using your POV on your PCS, other than for transoceanic travel, is always considered advantageous to the government. You may elect to travel by POV, common carrier, or be provided transportation in kind (at no charge). If you use your POV, you will be reimbursed $0.23 per mile, per authorized vehicle

</541> <542> Why is my Selective Reenlistment Bonus (SRB) different from the amount I expected? There are several reasons why your bonus payment may be different than the amount on your contract: Bonuses may be paid in installments - an initial payment of 50% is made on the effective date of the reenlistment, and then anniversary payments are split evenly and paid on the anniversary date for the enlistment period. You do not receive the full bonus in one lump sum payment. All bonus payments are taxed at 25% by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS), in addition to any applicable state tax. Taxes are deducted from the bonus amount when paid to you. If you elected to contribute any part of your bonus to the Thrift Savings Plan (TSP), that deduction was subtracted from the bonus payment. You may have reenlisted in a Combat Zone Tax Exclusion (CZTE) location, in which case your bonus would be paid tax free. For further information contact your servicing Personnel Office.

</542> <543> How are my authorized travel days determined? Your authorized travel days are determined by mode of transportation. Your Approving Official (AO) will designate which mode of transportation you are authorized/directed to use on your TDY orders/authorization. Generally, if you travel via government procured air transportation (you make arrangements through your local contract ticket office or CTO), you are authorized your actual travel time, via the most direct route, to get to your TDY destination. If you elect to travel via a mode of travel not authorized/directed by your AO, then you will be limited to your actual travel time not to exceed the travel time for the directed mode. This includes travel by privately owned conveyance (POC) not advantageous to the government. For travel by POC designated as advantageous to the government, you are authorized 1 travel day for each 400 miles of official distance; any remainder after dividing the total distance by 400 will result in an additional travel day.

</543> <544> When will I receive my Selective Reenlistment Bonus (SRB)? Bonus payments are usually deposited in your bank account within three to five days after your reenlistment paperwork has been received and verified by your Finance Office. Generally, your bonus will be a separate deposit and will not be included in your paycheck. However, it will be deposited into the same account as your regular pay. The initial payment, 50% of the SRB, will be released to your bank once the Finance Office has verified you did in fact reenlist and that a bonus was authorized. This means that you must provide reenlistment paperwork to your Finance Office. This should occur on the actual date of reenlistment. If you are away from your PDS on your reenlistment date, the signed documentation can be sent from the MPF to your finance office. Future installments will be automatically released to your bank account on the anniversary date of your reenlistment. Payments are made separately from your regular pay and are electronically deposited into your direct deposit bank account.

</545> <546> How many travel days do I get for Consecutive Overseas Tour (COT) / In Place Consecutive Overseas Tour (IPCOT)? Each leg of the journey is calculated independently with travel time allowed for each leg based on the mode(s) of travel used.

</546> <547> What are the maximum number of incentive pays I can receive concurrently? Enlisted: You may receive a maximum or two different incentive pay entitlements during the same period.
Officer: You may receive a maximum or two different incentive pay entitlements during the same period, in addition to aviation career incentive pay (non-AWACS), if applicable.

</547> <548> When I deploy, what happens to my Thrift Savings Plan (TSP) contributions? When you contribute to the TSP while serving in a Combat Zone Tax Exclusion (CZTE) area, you will not receive a direct tax benefit from those contributions because they have been excluded from your gross income. However, the contributions are designated as tax exempt and earnings on those contributions remain exempt too. When you make a withdrawal from your TSP account, money is taken from your total account balance in proportion from your taxable funds and your tax-exempt funds. The amount attributable to tax-exempt contributions will not be taxable.
The TSP will account for your tax-exempt contributions and will ensure that these amounts are not reported to the IRS as taxable income. Consequently, those contributions will not be subject to taxation when you withdraw them. Your quarterly participant statement will show your tax-exempt balance separately. Go to the Thrift Savings Plan Website for further information. To change your withholding for TSP, please use myPay. To change the allocation of your contributions between TSP funds, use the Thrift Savings Plan Website.

</548> <549> Which items of pay are subject to federal taxation? Military pays are considered taxable wages as defined by the DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 44 (Withholding of Income Tax) and are subject to federal and state income tax withholding. Examples of taxable items of pay include basic pay and incentive pays, such as flight pay. In addition to income taxes, basic pay only is subject to deduction for the Social Security and Medicare tax. Generally, allowances are not taxable. Examples of non-taxable allowances include Basic Allowance for Subsistence (BAS), Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH), and Family Separation Allowance (FSA). A notable exception is CONUS Cost of Living Allowance (C COLA), which is subject to withholding for federal and state tax.

</549> <550> Am I eligible for a Dislocation Allowance (DLA)? Your eligibility for DLA depends on your individual situation. If you have dependents, you are normally authorized DLA at the with-dependent rate when your dependents relocate in conjunction with a PCS. In other circumstances, you may be entitled to DLA when your dependents move in conjunction with closure or realignment of a military installation or move to a designated location as a result of an evacuation. If you are a member without dependents, you may be authorized DLA at the without-dependent rate when you relocate to a base where you are not assigned to government quarters or when you move in conjunction with closure or realignment of a military installation. The amount of your DLA is based on your dependency status and pay grade and is normally paid when your PCS travel voucher is paid. Click on the following link to check DLA Rates. If you still have questions about your eligibility for DLA, please contact your servicing Finance Office.

</550> <551> When will my last payment be made to the Thrift Savings Plan (TSP)? Military: Your last TSP contribution will be taken out of your pay the month prior to your Date of Separation (DOS). If you would like your TSP contribution to be withheld during your final month of active duty, contact your servicing Finance Office prior to your final month of active duty so they can process the request. For example, if you separate in May, your last TSP payment will be made in April, unless you submit a request to your Finance Office to have TSP deducted and paid during your DOS month. Civilian: Your TSP contributions will continue all the way to your last paycheck, unless you stop them sooner. To change your withholding for TSP, please use myPay. To change the allocation of your contributions between TSP funds, use the Thrift Savings Plan Website.

</551> <552> When am I eligible to receive dive pay? Active Duty: If you are entitled to basic pay, you are eligible for dive pay for periods during which you are assigned by orders to diving duty or required to maintain proficiency as a diver, as outlined in the DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 11 Para 110101 (Dive Pay Requirements). Your monthly rate of pay for diving duty will vary depending on the type of diving duty performed, i.e. scuba or pararescue. The first two DoDFMR links below have the most current rates. Reserve: Besides the requirements for active duty personnel above, you are required to be on orders for 30 days or more to be eligible for dive pay.

</552> <553> How much can I get advanced for PCS Travel? Normally, your Government Travel Charge Card (GTCC) is required to be used for all PCS expenses. If you are exempt from GTCC use, you may get an advance for 100% of your estimated per diem, mileage, and dislocation allowance.
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 9 Chap 3 Para 030501 (Use of the GTCC for official government travel) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437435000&usg=AFQjCNGb-MI0EKRzAr8CLhAp5VCsf9fcgg

</553> <554> Will I be paid if I am nearing my expiration term of service (ETS) and my record does not reflect my reenlistment? Yes, you will be paid. If your record has not been updated to reflect your reenlistment, and if you did not receive a paycheck or you are not projected to receive a paycheck, an emergency partial pay may be warranted. Emergency partial payments must be authorized via letter from your Commander/First Sergeant stating the purpose for the payment. Before going to your Finance Office, check with your Personnel Office to ensure they have all the required reenlistment paperwork. If your personnel records are updated, proceed to your Finance Office. Emergency partial payments are allowed up to the amount of accrued entitlements to date and are intended to prevent financial hardship. An emergency partial payment is a payment deemed time sensitive due to an unforeseen set of circumstances that calls for immediate action. Emergency partial payments are made in an expedited manner via EFT.
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 36.5 (Partial Payments) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437436000&usg=AFQjCNFwbC1YeuQIKMcXOJIzuyE48ny5zA
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 32 Para 320202 Emergency Partial Payments) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437436000&usg=AFQjCNHBs2m1_Fvg82fHM0aFamb0SLfZJw
</554> <555> If I didn't sign up for the Montgomery GI Bill (MGIB) in Basic Training, can I enroll now? </555> <556> How do I know if my dependent qualifies for student dependent travel? Your dependent is authorized student dependent travel if you are stationed OCONUS and your dependent is authorized to reside at your new permanent duty station. Also, your dependent must be unmarried, under 23 years old, and physically attending either a Department of Defense Education Activity (DODEA) school overseas or an accredited school in the CONUS.

</558> <559> Am I authorized to receive Dislocation Allowance (DLA)? Generally, you are authorized to receive DLA if you relocate your dependents in conjunction with your PCS move, provided it is not your final move upon separation or retirement. If you are without dependents, normally you are authorized DLA if you do not occupy government quarters for more than 60 days at your new permanent duty station. Go to $JTR_Chap_5_Part_A_Sec10_Para_5438 for information on when a DLA is/is not payable. For Reservists, orders must state that PCS allowances are authorized.
Regulation: $JTR_Chap_5_Part_A_Sec10_Para_5438
Regulation: $JTR_Chap_5_Part_A_Sec10_Para_5438
</559> <560> As a Cadet, why don’t I see my NAF TDY in DTS? NAF travel is a manual process that is not entered into DTS. Manual travel voucher documentation is submitted and paid through the NAF Office. If you have any questions, please contact the Cadet Clubs Resource Management (CCRM) Office.
noref
</560> <561> What receipts do I need to submit with my TDY voucher? When submitting a TDY voucher, you need to submit receipts for lodging, regardless of the amount, and receipts for any other expense of $75.00 or more. For registration fees, an itemized receipt or statement indicating the meals and lodging that were provided to you is required if the order does not specify this information. If a required receipt is lost or otherwise unobtainable, you must submit a Lost Receipt Form (found in eFinance) including a statement explaining the circumstances. Click here to access eFinance: eFinance. Note: Include (or upload) a copy of your airline receipt for both DTS and non-DTS travel claims, even if you made your reservations through DTS.

</565> <566> How do I claim tax exempt status for Federal taxes? You can claim exemption from withholding if you had no tax liability in the previous year and anticipate no tax liability in the current year. Claim the exemption by completing the W-4 Form, Employee's Withholding Allowance Certificate, and submitting it to your Finance Office. The exemption is only good for the current calendar year and you need to file a new W-4 each year if you continue to remain exempt. If something changes and you determine that you will have a tax liability in the current year, you need to file a new W-4.

</567> <568> How does Basic Allowance Housing (BAH) work for a dual military couple? If you are a dual military couple without dependents, you will both receive single rate BAH. If you have dependents, then one of you will receive the with dependent rate and the other will receive the single rate of BAH. Who receives the with dependent rate is determined by your election. If you are unable to agree as to who should receive the with dependent rate, it will default to the senior ranking individual.
Regulation: $JTR_Chap_10_Part_C_Table_10C_1

</568> <569> Am I eligible to change my state of legal residence? Yes, you are eligible to change your state of legal residence, provided you have proper documentation. In most cases, you must actually reside in the new state at the time of your intent to make it your permanent home. Your intent to make the new state your permanent home may be indicated by one of the following: Registering to vote in the new state Purchasing residential property or an unimproved residential lot in the new state Titling and registering your automobile(s) in the new state Notifying the new state of your previous legal residence/domicile and the change in your state of legal residence Preparing a new last will and testament which indicates your new state of legal residence
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 44 Para 440106 (State and Local Taxes) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437442000&usg=AFQjCNEcTPQtDx0iKArPkwFKxnZAfN6B3w

</570> <571> Is my Hardship Duty Pay (HDP) entitlement prorated? Your HDP may be prorated depending on the type of HDP received. There are two types of HDP; HDP-L (Location) and HDP-M (Mission). HDP-L is payable to members when assigned duty in designated locations (PCS or TDY) for periods of more than 30 days duration. This type of HDP is prorated for partial months. HDP-M is payable at the full monthly rate regardless of time served in any particular month.

</573> <574> Will my leave be tax free? If you have accumulated leave from a designated Combat Zone Tax Exclusion (CZTE) or qualified hazardous duty location, your leave will be tax exempt. However, if you use leave after departing the CZTE area, the tax exempt leave is used first. When the leave is taken and charged against your balance, your federal and applicable state taxable wages will be reduced by the number of tax exempt leave days taken.

</574> <575> As a Cadet, how much leave do I have? Cadets do not accrue leave. Cadets may be on authorized absence away from USAFA on an approved Scheduling Committee Action (SCA). Contact your Air Officer Commanding (AOC) for assistance with SCA approval.
noref
</575> <576> I am a Reservist, when will my voucher be paid? Once you have submitted your completed voucher, orders, and all required receipts to your local Finance Office, payment should be made within ten business days. To file your travel settlement voucher, please use eFinance. For further issues, contact your servicing Finance Office.
Related Link: eFinance https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.my.af.mil/efinanceprod&sa=D&ust=1558682437444000&usg=AFQjCNHuwAHqx8K7dGZ3dqb3GsY8AXTZrw
</576> <577> I have a debt; can I appeal the validity of the debt and how do I appeal? You can appeal the validity of any debt. To request an appeal of a debt, except excess cost on shipment of personal property, you'll need to prepare, address, and present to your commander a signed statement in two copies. It should include: - Identification of charge against your account - Your reason for protesting the debt - Evidence refuting debt, including documents, receipt, correspondence, and description of circumstances or events for which verifying evidence is not available. If you have evidence not immediately available, describe it and state when it can be furnished. You should identify dates, official designations or organizations, and other information as exactly as possible. The original and one copy needs to submitted to your servicing Finance Office.
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 69.20 (Indebtedness - Appeal) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437445000&usg=AFQjCNEX0jkShAeVWEcO3BnZBjgAqqHgVQ
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 70 Sec 70A 70.8 (Rebuttal of Excess Cost) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437445000&usg=AFQjCNEX0jkShAeVWEcO3BnZBjgAqqHgVQ
</577> <578> What is the timeline on travel reimbursements? The AF travel processing standard is currently ten business days from the time a computable travel voucher is submitted to the Finance Office.
noref
noref
</578> <579> Is my entitlement to Hostile Fire Pay / Imminent Danger Pay (HFP/IDP) pro-rated? Until 31 December 2011, Hostile Fire Pay (HFP) and Imminent Danger Pay (IDP) were both paid at the full monthly rate and not prorated. However, effective 31 December 2011, a change in the law required IDP to be paid on a prorated basis, based on the number of days you perform duty in one of the designated areas. For example, if you perform duty in an IDP area for 10 days in a month, you will only be paid IDP for 10 days. HFP continues to be paid on a monthly basis. In other words, if you meet the criteria on any day in the month, you'll be paid HFP for the entire month. Also note below the special circumstances in which HFP, as well as IDP are prorated: You are subject to a total forfeiture of pay and allowances, or You are in an excess leave status, or Your entitlement to HFP/IDP is earned during the month you enter active duty, or Your entitlement to HFP/IDP is earned during the month you separate from service. The current rate for HFP and IDP is $225 per month.
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 13.6 (Proration of HFP or IDP Entitlement) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437445000&usg=AFQjCNEX0jkShAeVWEcO3BnZBjgAqqHgVQ
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 10 Para 100102 (Adminstration of Deteminations of Fact) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437446000&usg=AFQjCNEo1G6Xwyzx-cXLkyDdl6BPHPPOHQ
</579> <580> I just had a change in dependents, how do I update my Cost of Living Allowance (COLA) to reflect the change? Once command sponsorship is completed by your servicing Personnel Office, you will be required to update the number of dependents using eFinance. You will need to upload (scan) all official documentation (birth certificate or marriage license and approved command sponsorship) to the eFinance system. Reservists: Please take all your official documentation to your servicing Finance Office to update your pay.
Regulation: JTR Chap 9 Part B Para 9130 (Uniformed Members - COLA For A Member With Dependent) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/travelreg.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437446000&usg=AFQjCNHemMsxOZ2BCHuWTeB49ht9g6Pppw
Related Link: eFinance https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.my.af.mil/efinanceprod&sa=D&ust=1558682437446000&usg=AFQjCNEMlYWKHtZ3PGWPWieQWZyHKtcchA
</580> <581> How is Temporary Lodging Expense (TLE) computed? There are several steps involved in computing TLE. Below is the computation for the most common scenario. See the link below for computation questions related to your specific situation. Step 1: Determine the applicable M&IE and lodging locality per diem rates for your location. The applicable M&IE and lodging locality per diem rates can be found at the link below.
Step 2: Determine your applicable per diem percentage. Using the table below, calculate the percentage you are allowed to claim based on your specific situation. Number of Eligible Persons Occupying Temporary Quarters Percentage Applicable Member or 1 dependent 65% Member and 1 dependent, or 2 dependents only 100% For each additional dependent age 12 and over add 35% For each additional dependent under age 12 add 25% For a member with multiple dependents occupying the same temporary lodging, add each dependent starting with the oldest dependent to get the correct percentage rate as shown above. A member with two dependents, one over 12 and one under 12, will have an applicable percentage of 125% since the member and dependent over 12 is 100%, and the additional dependent under 12 is 25%.
Step 3: Determine daily Meals & Incidental Expenses (M&IE) and ceiling for lodging. Multiply the appropriate percentage calculated in Step 2 by the applicable M&IE locality per diem rate and by the applicable lodging locality per diem rate determined in Step 1. This will give you your maximum allowed amount for both types of expenses.
Step 4: Determine lodging. Compare the actual daily lodging cost (including lodging taxes) to the lodging cost ceiling calculated in Step 3. The lesser of the two amounts is your authorized lodging expense.
Step 5: Determine gross daily equivalency. Add the lodging amount in Step 4 to the daily M&IE rate calculated in Step 3.
Step 6: Determine applicable daily rate. The standard TLE ceiling is currently $290. Per the JTR, TLE cannot exceed this amount. Compare $290 with the amount found in Step 5. You are authorized to claim the lesser of these two amounts for that specific day.
Regulation: JTR Chap 5 Part A Para 5434 (Uniformed Members - Temporary Lodging - CONUS Temporary Lodging Expense - TLE) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/travelreg.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437446000&usg=AFQjCNHemMsxOZ2BCHuWTeB49ht9g6Pppw
Related Link: TLE Calculator https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.my.af.mil/gcss-af/USAF/AFP40/d/sA1FBF31D23D21F6B0123ED377B730575/Files/TLE_Calculator.htm&sa=D&ust=1558682437446000&usg=AFQjCNFyPQZvl7QhBXeuEtCOQyhVYon-1g
</581> <582> Which Civilian PCS allowances are subject to Federal Income Tax Withholding (FITW)? The following allowances are subject to FITW: Enroute travel (Meals and incidental expenses only) Mobile home movement House hunting trip Temporary Quarters Subsistence Expense (TQSE) Real estate expense Miscellaneous Expense Allowance (MEA)

</582> <583> What documentation do I need to turn in with my personally procured move (PPM, formerly DITY)? The following documentation needs to be provided to the Traffic Management Office (TMO) with regard to PPM moves: DD Form 2278 (Application For Do It Yourself Move And Counseling Checklist) with TMO-constructed Government Bill of Lading (GBL) or local contract cost along with your certification. Copy of certified scale tickets (gross and empty) or constructed weight statements. When the conveyance and the contents both qualify as household goods, (for example, a boat or boat trailer) only a gross weight certificate is acceptable. Your certification of expenses. Your signature is required. Copies of receipts for expenses that are $75 or more (keep your original receipts for I.R.S. audit purposes). DD Form 1351-2 (Travel Voucher or Sub Voucher) Standard Form 1038 (Advance of Funds Application and Account) A copy of your registration for your boat and/or trailer, if applicable. A copy of the travel order if PPM was TDY or PCS related. For local moves, a copy of the housing order, AF Form 150 (Drayage/Storage Authorization - Government Quarters), which is provided by the Housing office. TMO will compute your claim and turn your paperwork in to the local Finance Office, who will then send your package to the AFFSC to be processed.

</583> <584> How do I start Basic Allowance for Subsistence (BAS)? Active Duty: BAS is automatically started upon completion of basic training. However, meal deductions may apply. See your Unit Commander's Support Staff (CSS) for more details, as they are responsible for initiating the required paperwork to terminate dining facility meal deductions. Reserves: BAS is automatically started upon completion of basic training or upon submission of orders for pay on an AF Form IMT 938 (Request and Authorization for Active Duty Training/Active Duty Tour).

</584> <585> Can I get my money back if I have not paid all of the $1,200 Montgomery GI Bill (MGIB) contribution? No, the enrollment decision made during basic military training is irrevocable. If you have any other questions pertaining to MGIB contribution refunds you will need to visit your Education Office.

</585> <586> If I take leave in conjunction with a TDY, do I process my leave through LeaveWeb? For non-DTS travel vouchers (manual vouchers prepared on a DD Form 1351-2 (Travel Voucher or Sub Voucher), or vouchers prepared using eFinance), you do not use LeaveWeb; your leave needs to be reflected on your travel settlement voucher and Finance will charge your leave off the travel voucher. For DTS travel vouchers (orders and voucher prepared in the Defense Travel System (DTS)), you are required to use LeaveWeb or your time and attendance reporting system for any leave taken during your TDY. Additionally, you must enter your leave date(s) in your travel authorization/order's 'Per Diem Entitlements' section in DTS.

</586> <587> How does Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH) work while I'm in a travel status? While you are in travel status you will continue to receive BAH at the rate that applies to you. If you are returning to the CONUS from the OCONUS, traveling PCS between OCONUS locations, or you are en route to your first duty station (other than a tech school) you will receive Basic Allowance for Housing -Transit rate (BAH-T or Non-Locality BAH) while in travel or leave status between Permanent Duty Stations provided you are not assigned Gov't quarters. Go to BAH Non-Locality Rates link for current rates. In the Non-Locality BAH folder select the file for the current year's non-locality BAH rates. If you are traveling from one CONUS PDS to another CONUS PDS, you will receive the BAH rate for your old PDS until the day prior to the day you in process at your new PDS, at which time you will receive BAH for the new CONUS PDS.

</587> <588> Why do I owe money on Relocation Income Tax Allowance (RITA)? You will owe money only if your Withholding Tax Allowance (WTA) was more in year one than what was authorized for RITA in year two.
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 9 Chap 6 Para 061201 (Relocation Income Tax Allowance - RITA - Allowance) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437450000&usg=AFQjCNEy34GWFawERHClB2rC3atc2ngysQ
</588> <589> How much money do I have to give my spouse to constitute support for dependent Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH)? When you provide your dependent with the difference between your "with dependent" rate and the applicable single rate BAH for your grade, that constitutes support. Proof of support is usually not required unless there is evidence that support is not being provided or a complaint from the dependent for non-support arises. If you are the non-custodial parent residing in single type government quarters and are paying child support, you will be authorized a flat rate of BAH called Basic Allowance for Housing-Difference (BAH-DIFF). The amount of child support you provide must be equal to or greater than the flat rate of BAH-DIFF. If the child support is lower than the BAH-DIFF, you will not be provided the allowance.
Regulation: $JTR_Chap_10_Part_BPara10106E
Related Link: BAH Rates https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/bahCalc.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437450000&usg=AFQjCNGMojLq5wysFqBLQK6flLDaVryyNQ
</589> <590> When my "IMA-Category" changed from 24 to 48 periods, why did I not receive the points or pay? When you change pay categories, for example B to A, the number of paid Inactive Duty Training (IDT)/ Unit Training Assembly (UTA) allowed during that Fiscal Year (FY) may be prorated to something between 24 and 48 periods. You should consult your local Base IMA Administrator (BIMAA) to determine what your maximum for the year is. Beginning the next FY, the maximum number of paid IDTs/UTAs will automatically re-set to the actual number allowed for your category. Another reason why you did not receive points or pay may be that your AF Form 40A (Record of Individual Inactive Duty Training) was processed incorrectly or missed a payroll cut-off and you will be paid on the next available payroll.
Your local BIMAA is your best point of contact for concerns.
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 3 Chap 8.2 (Reserve Component: Inactive Duty Training - Change in Authorized Number of Paid UTAs or IDTs) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/production/1/saf_fm/publication/afman65-116v3/afman65-116v3.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437451000&usg=AFQjCNEyjJvSKN50FbulZyqcNIuUHHgfEw

</590> <591> Am I eligible to receive Dislocation Allowance (DLA)? You are eligible to receive DLA if one of the following statements apply to you:
If you have dependents, you are authorized with dependent DLA when: Relocating in connection with a PCS Moving in connection with the closure or realignment of a military installation Moving to a designated place incident to an evacuation If you do not have dependents, you are authorized DLA when: Relocating in connection with a PCS to a PDS where single government quarters are not assigned Moving in connection with the closure or realignment of a U.S. installation DLA is not payable upon separation, retirement and in conjunction with your first PCS move (DLA is payable if you have dependents and they relocate during your first PCS move). To file a settlement voucher to claim DLA, please use the PCS In-Processing System (PIPS) module in eFinance Workspace

Regulation: JTR Chap 5 Part A Sec 10 (Uniformed Members - Dislocation Allowance - DLA) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/travelreg.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437451000&usg=AFQjCNHR3EFrwOiEgiaEKp3G9gut4x0bNg

</591> <592> What is the Cadet Budget? The Finance Office develops an annual cadet budget that incorporates cadet expenses (processed by payroll deduction) and cadet pay. The budget is prepared by individual class and is an estimate of cadet pay, deductions, discretionary pay, and debt levels for a typical cadet.
Related Link: USAF Academy Financial Management CoP https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.my.af.mil/afknprod/community/views/home.aspx?Filter%3DFA-FM-XH-01&sa=D&ust=1558682437452000&usg=AFQjCNGSOLFTtnIE7mV1DWN3h4tpLCmA3g
</592> <593> What can I be reimbursed for Emergency Leave / Emergency Visitation Travel (EVT)? Uniformed Members: An eligible member on emergency leave and/or one or more eligible dependents with a personal emergency are authorized transportation between authorized locations. Air is the only authorized transportation mode. Reimbursement for transportation costs cannot exceed the cost of government procured commercial air transportation between authorized locations. Civilian Employees: Eligible civilian employees assigned to an OCONUS location traveling under Emergency Visitation Travel (EVT) rules are eligible for reimbursement of transportation cost from the airport serving the employee’s PDS (or applicable originating point) to the airport serving the destination authorized for EVT and return; airport taxes; and air transportation/ground transportation between interim airports. Employees are not eligible for reimbursement for ground transportation between PDS/home/destination and the airport, per diem, nor excess baggage/unaccompanied baggage charges.
Regulation: JTR Chap 7 Part A Para 7010 (Uniformed Members - Emergency Leave - Transportation in Personal Emergencies) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/travelreg.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437452000&usg=AFQjCNEpMAHBYYzPpJ2H2WNsREbsO1xlmg
Regulation: JTR Chap 7 Part A Para 7015 (Uniformed Members - Personal Emergencies For a Member on TDY or Away From Home Port) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/travelreg.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437452000&usg=AFQjCNEpMAHBYYzPpJ2H2WNsREbsO1xlmg
Regulation: JTR Chap 7 Part A Para 7020 (Civilian Employees - Emergency Visitation Travel - EVT) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/travelreg.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437452000&usg=AFQjCNEpMAHBYYzPpJ2H2WNsREbsO1xlmg
</593> <594> When will my promotion/demotion be reflected in my paycheck? Active Duty: Promotions and demotions are generally reflected in the paycheck following the promotion/demotion. All promotions and demotions are processed by the Air Force Personnel Center (AFPC) and a transaction is sent to DFAS to update your pay. For example, if your promotion is effective on the first of the month, this will normally be reflected in your pay on the 15th of the month. As another example, assume that your promotion or demotion is effective on the 10th of the month. The effective date is after the processing deadline for the 15th payday, so you should expect the change to be reflected in your end-of-month pay.
Reserve: Promotions and demotions are generally reflected in the paycheck following the promotion/demotion. Enlisted promotions and demotions are processed by your servicing Personnel Office. Officer promotions and demotions are processed by the Air Reserve Personnel Center (ARPC). In both cases, the transactions are sent to DFAS to update your pay.
noref
noref
</594> <595> Can I split my authorized Temporary Lodging Expense (TLE) between the old and new PDS? Yes, you may split your authorized number of TLE days between your old and new PDS. TLE can only be split between two CONUS PDS's.
Regulation: JTR Chap 5 Part A Para 5434 (Uniformed Members - Temporary Lodging - CONUS Temporary Lodging Expense - TLE) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/travelreg.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437452000&usg=AFQjCNEpMAHBYYzPpJ2H2WNsREbsO1xlmg
Regulation: JTR Chap 5 Part A Para 5434 (Uniformed Members - Temporary Lodging - CONUS Temporary Lodging Expense - TLE) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/travelreg.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437453000&usg=AFQjCNEbF0QDvV-MgbcHgcaSYmveoK9d5Q
</595> <596> What is my new basic pay rate? Your new basic pay rate will take effect on the day that you are promoted, demoted, or due your longevity pay increase. If that day falls on any day other than the first of the month, your basic pay rate will be a mix between the old and new base pay rates for that month, followed by the new base pay rate thereafter. For example, if you are promoted, demoted or due a longevity increase on the 10th of the month, the first 9 days of the month will be at the old rate while the rest of the days in that month will be at the new rate.
To determine the amount of basic pay for the month of promotion, demotion or longevity, take both the old and new basic pay rates and divide them by 30. Take the resulting figures and multiply them for the number of days in the month that they apply. Regardless of actual days in a month, always use 30 days for your calculation. Remember, the day you are promoted, demoted or due a longevity increase is paid at the new basic pay rate.
Regulation: DFAS Military Pay Tables https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.dfas.mil/militarymembers/payentitlements/militarypaytables.html&sa=D&ust=1558682437453000&usg=AFQjCNFIbyI3mefQ5M1PuCn-aUUR2CBong
Regulation: DFAS Military Pay Tables https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.dfas.mil/militarymembers/payentitlements/militarypaytables.html&sa=D&ust=1558682437453000&usg=AFQjCNFIbyI3mefQ5M1PuCn-aUUR2CBong
</596> <597> What are the conditions of the combat zone tax exclusion (CZTE) entitlement? You are authorized the combat zone tax exclusion when you perform duty in an area designated by Executive Order as a combat zone. In certain circumstances, you may be authorized the exclusion when you perform duty outside the designated area that is in direct support of military operations in the zone. You must perform the duty during a period when the area is designated as a combat zone. Please reference the link below for conditions of CZTE entitlement and for a list of tax exempt countries.
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 44 (Withholding of Income Tax) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437453000&usg=AFQjCNFdyif_zvcMrwAESFEbCxwId_ihJw
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 44 Figure 44-2 (Collection of Delinquet Taxes by Installment - Change of Member's Status) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437453000&usg=AFQjCNFdyif_zvcMrwAESFEbCxwId_ihJw
</597> <598> How do I make a retroactive contribution to my Thrift Savings Plan (TSP) account? If it is verified that your TSP form was not processed by your Finance Office in a timely manner, you can make a retroactive or make-up TSP contribution. Please contact your servicing Finance Office for instructions on how to submit your retroactive contribution.
Regulation (Active Duty Only): AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 68.13 (Thrift Savings Plan - Make-up Contributions) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437454000&usg=AFQjCNGbee0HSP0vP_S75T7rkdfjzAlfhQ
Regulation (Reserve Only): AFMAN 65-116 Vol 3 Chap 50.13 (Reserve Component:) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/production/1/saf_fm/publication/afman65-116v3/afman65-116v3.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437454000&usg=AFQjCNHvLbwnRDEpUnQy8sgQOwJ7yqRiiA
</598> <599> Am I eligible for Family Separation Allowance TDY (FSA-T) if my spouse and I are a 'Military to Military' couple? If you reside together immediately before the TDY and the TDY is more than 30 days, you are entitled to FSA-T, provided your military spouse does not reside at or near the TDY location nor visit for more than 30 days. Additionally, both of you may be entitled to receive FSA-T concurrently, if: You have dependents, and Both of you were residing together with your dependents immediately before your departure, and You are both TDY at the same time.
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 27 Para 270103 (Entitlement Provisions - Family Separation Allowance) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437454000&usg=AFQjCNGd0iTmfwewRG4V0l7_7YyCFR5hoA
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 27 Para 270103 (Entitlement Provisions - Family Separation Allowance) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437454000&usg=AFQjCNGd0iTmfwewRG4V0l7_7YyCFR5hoA
</599> <600> When I PCS, what per diem allowances are my dependents eligible for? Your dependent's per diem allowance is based off your allowance as the uniformed member. For travel by Privately Owned Conveyance (POC), your per diem is at the flat standard CONUS rate. For travel by commercial means, your per diem is at the rate for the new PDS or the rate for the delay point if you stop overnight. You are not authorized per diem for delays of leave or personal reasons. Per diem for the dependents is 3/4 of the member's applicable rate for each dependent age 12 or older and 1/2 of the member's rate for each dependent under age 12. If your spouse or designated child (age 12 and over) travels separately from you, they will be authorized to the same rate of per diem as you, not the reduced rate. Other dependents traveling with them would be factored the same as if they were with you. Go to Per Diem Rates for more information. Additionally, your dependent will be authorized mileage if traveling by POC. Mileage is a flat rate for each POC used by authorized travelers. If you use more than two POCs, then you must obtain special authorization through your servicing Personnel Office in order to be reimbursed. Mileage can be found in JTR Chap 2 Part I Para 2605 (MALT Rate).
Regulation: JTR Chap 2 Part I Para 2605 (MALT Rate) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/travelreg.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437454000&usg=AFQjCNGpS2B-d55V-pYE4Nc4wLFyoiEWOQ
Regulation: JTR Chap 5 Part A Para 5154 (Uniformed Members - POC Use on Permanent Duty Travel) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/travelreg.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437454000&usg=AFQjCNGpS2B-d55V-pYE4Nc4wLFyoiEWOQ
Related Link: Per Diem Rates https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/perdiemCalc.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437454000&usg=AFQjCNF0_TFyRiuA_eyvKUbdUxwke5P_vA
</600> <601> If I am driving my privately owned vehicle (POV), then how many days of travel am I authorized? POV travel as Advantageous to the Government: If your orders state it is advantageous to the government to travel by POV, then you are entitled to 1 day of travel time for every 400 miles. If the excess distance is 1 or more miles, after dividing the total number miles by 400, then 1 additional day of travel time is authorized. If the official mileage from your PDS to your TDY location is fewer than 400 miles, then only 1 travel day is allowed. POV travel Not Advantageous to the Government: Uniformed Members: You are limited to the constructive travel time for travel by common carrier (i.e. commercial air), usually 1 day each way, for travel to and from the TDY location; excess time is charged as leave. However, for funded TDYs 16 days or more, Air Force policy allows permissive travel time (not chargeable as leave & no per diem payable) for the number of travel days as calculated above. Civilian Employees: You are limited to the constructive travel time for travel by common carrier (i.e. commercial air), usually 1 day each way, for travel to and from the TDY location; excess time is charged as leave.
Regulation: AFI 65-114 Chap 4.5 (Permissive Travel Time) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/production/1/saf_fm/publication/afi65-114/afi65-114.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437455000&usg=AFQjCNHY2_aPnwpPBR5D-ORMxw_mmQ97uw
Regulation: JTR Chap 4 Part G Para 4760 (Travel Time) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/travelreg.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437455000&usg=AFQjCNEJMJ_31o73UDuayyC7eYtBWtmGfg
Regulation: JTR Chap 3 Part A Para 3025 (Travel-Transportation Policy - Travel Time) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/travelreg.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437455000&usg=AFQjCNEJMJ_31o73UDuayyC7eYtBWtmGfg
</601> <602> How will my bonus payment be taxed? Your bonus will be taxed at 25% for federal income tax withholding (FITW). The amount of state income tax withholding (SITW) varies depending on the state of legal residence you claim for tax purposes. However, if you earn your bonus (reenlist, extend, or sign agreement) in a month when you are entitled to the Combat Zone Tax Exclusion (CZTE), your bonus and future installments are not taxed. If you are an officer and are due a bonus that was earned in a CZTE area, your tax exclusion for the bonus is limited to the highest rate of basic pay for an enlisted member plus the amount of hostile fire pay payable to you during that month.
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 56 Sec 56A 56.5.1 (Federal Income Tax Withholding - FITW) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437455000&usg=AFQjCNGQLW_wYS65IMEMBtcI8Bwro3uKTQ
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 44 Table 44-1 (Taxibility of Items of Military Pay and Allowances) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437455000&usg=AFQjCNEkGeSzt_qNUXX23S_OIsPhYvEWpQ
</602> <603> What rate should I be getting for incentive pay? Rates vary based on your circumstances (i.e. Aviation Service Date, Number of Jumps, Years in service, Grade, Officer/Enlisted etc.).
Related Link: DFAS Military Pay Tables https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.dfas.mil/militarymembers/payentitlements/militarypaytables.html&sa=D&ust=1558682437455000&usg=AFQjCNHMCbq2T7liUfoA1H3kJxqqXG5RCg

</603> <604> How many days am I authorized PCS Travel? Generally, one travel day is allowed for each 400 miles of official distance of ordered travel. If you take the total miles driven and divide it by 400 and the excess distance is 1 or more miles after dividing the total official distance by 400, one additional travel day is allowed. When the total official distance is 400 or fewer miles, only one day of travel time is allowed. For common carrier transportation, actual travel time for the direct route is authorized, normally one day.
Regulation: JTR Chap 3 Part A Para 3025 (Travel-Transportation Policy - Travel Time) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://www.defensetravel.dod.mil/site/travelreg.cfm&sa=D&ust=1558682437455000&usg=AFQjCNEJMJ_31o73UDuayyC7eYtBWtmGfg

</604> <605> If I am in a Combat Zone Tax Exclusion (CZTE) location, then is my Selective Reenlistment Bonus (SRB) tax exempt? SRB payments are only tax-exempt if you reenlisted in a month during which you were authorized CZTE. In such a situation, the initial payments and subsequent installments would both be tax-exempt.
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 44 Para 440102 (Wages Not Subject to Withholding of Federal and State Income Tax) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437456000&usg=AFQjCNFBS_VHBSWzLXleMTIRQk5neRfXyg

</605> <606> How do I start my Aerial Flight Incentive Pays such as Hazardous Duty Incentive Pay (HDIP), Aviation Career Incentive Pay (ACIP), or Career Enlisted Flight Incentive Pay (CEFIP)? If you are entitled to flight pays such as ACIP, HDIP, CEFIP, then you need to go to your Host Aviation Resource Management (HARM) Office. For ACIP or HDIP, the HARM Office will initiate an AF Form 1887 (Request and Authorization for Aeronautical Orders), initiate a case management system (CMS) case, and will complete any and all necessary documentation to submit to the Finance Office for processing. For CEFIP, the HARM Office will also initiate a CMS case and will refer it to DFAS for processing.
Please contact your HARM Office for any questions regarding the status of these flight pays.

</606> <607> How much leave can I take enroute on my TDY or PCS? TDY: You are authorized to take as much leave in conjunction with your TDY as necessary based on your supervisor or commander approval. Normally, leave must be approved in your orders or your Defense Travel System (DTS) travel authorization, however, any travel time taken which exceeds the authorized travel time will be charged as leave. If the requested number of leave days will exceed your current leave balance, you will be in Advance Leave status and must obtain commander approval.
PCS: For PCS leave you are authorized to take as much leave as you need, however, you must arrive at your new Permanent Duty Station (PDS) on or before your Report Not Later Than Date (RNLTD). If the number of leave days exceeds your current leave balance you will be in Advance Leave status upon arrival at your new PDS.

</607> <608> Does my BAH/OHA change when my child turns 18 or 21? If your sole unmarried dependent for BAH/OHA purposes turns 21 years old, with-dependent rate BAH/OHA stops the day before the child's 21st birthday. However, if your sole dependent child is a full time student, payment of with-dependent rate continues until the child's 23rd birthday provided your child is dependent upon you for over 1/2 of their support. Additionally, a child that is incapacitated and over the age of 21 may qualify as a dependent for BAH/OHA purposes, subject to a secondary dependency determination. Please contact your local finance office for more details.
Regulation: $JTR_Chap_10_Part_BPara10108
Regulation: $JTR_Chap_10_Part_A_Table_10A2
</608> <609> Can I get Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH) for my dependent(s) if I am living in the dorms? Your entitlement, if any, will depend on the circumstances. If you are living in the dorm and paying child support you may be entitled to receive BAH-Differential (DIFF) if the amount of child support you pay is equal to or greater than the BAH-Differential rate. BAH-Differential rates are in a table along with BAH transit and BAH partial rates. Follow the BAH Non-Locality Rates link to the Defense Travel Management Office (DTMO) website. In the Non-Locality BAH folder select the file for the current year's non-locality BAH rates. In other circumstances such as when you are on a dependent restricted tour (e.g. Osan AB) or assigned to a location where dependent travel is restricted (e.g. pipeline student), you will continue to draw BAH at the with dependent rate based on your authorized dependent's location. Follow the BAH Rates link to determine the amount of your BAH at the with dependent rate.

</610> <611> Does changing my state of legal residence change my home of record? No, changing your state of legal residence for tax withholding purposes does not change your Home of Record (HOR). To change your state of legal residence, please use eFinance.

</611> <612> When will I get paid for my TDY voucher? The standard TDY voucher processing timeline is 10 duty days from the date your voucher is received at the Air Force Financial Services Center (AFFSC).

</612> <613> How much am I entitled to receive for Reserve Funeral Honors Duty Allowance (FHDA)? When you perform funeral honors duty for a minimum of two hours, you are entitled to either $50 or one day of basic pay for your grade and years of service. You can only be paid one Funeral Honors Duty Allowance (FHDA) per calendar day. Federal and state income tax, if applicable, is withheld from your entitlement.
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 58 Para 580107 (Funeral Honors Duty Allowance - FHDA) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437460000&usg=AFQjCNHC75W2Ju7Xj41k6GUHTjJW12rU-Q
</613> <614> Is mileage reimbursable for my House Hunting Trip (HHT)? If a private automobile is authorized on your orders, then you can be paid mileage at the PCS mileage rate found in the JTR.

Regulation: $JTR_Chap_5_Part_B_Sec_3
</614> <615> When will I receive my disability severance / separation pay payment? Your final disability severance / separation pay payment will be included in your final pay upon separation or retirement. Normally, you will receive this payment via direct deposit on your date of separation or the next available business day. If your separation date falls on a weekend or holiday, then the payment date will be the first business day after your separation date.
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 35 (Separation Payments) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437460000&usg=AFQjCNHC75W2Ju7Xj41k6GUHTjJW12rU-Q
Regulation: DODFMR Vol 7A Chap 35 (Separation Payments) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://comptroller.defense.gov/fmr.aspx&sa=D&ust=1558682437460000&usg=AFQjCNHC75W2Ju7Xj41k6GUHTjJW12rU-Q
</615> <616> How does the advance pay process/request work? Advance pay is intended to assist with out-of-pocket expenses that exceed or precede reimbursements incurred in a duty location change, and are expenses that are not typical of day-to-day military living. Advance pay is only authorized in the event of a PCS move or a deployment for more than 365 days to an area subject to hostile fire/imminent danger pay. PCS moves from OCONUS to CONUS for the purpose of separation or retirement are not authorized PCS advance pay. The amount of advance pay that you may receive is limited to a maximum amount of three month's basic pay less deductions. Advance pay, once approved, will be electronically deposited into your bank account. Requests for advance pay are documented on a DD Form 2560 (Advance Pay Certification/Authorization Form). Your unit Commander is the approval authority for advance pay in the following circumstances: You are in pay grades E-1 through E-3 regardless of amount or repayment schedule. You are in a pay grade of E-4 or higher and: Amount requested is more than one month's base pay less deductions Repayment is requested for more than 12 months Payment is requested between 30 and 90 days of PCS departure or 60 to 180 days after PCS arrival Normally, it is only under extenuating circumstances that a commander will approve you to receive your advance 90 days prior to, or within 180 days after you PCS In all other circumstances your signature is all that is required Bring your completed DD Form 2560 (Advance Pay Certification/Authorization Form), along with a copy of your PCS orders, to your local Finance Office. When requesting an overseas housing allowance (OHA), it must be approved by the unit commander and the housing officer. You must show proof of expenses before you can receive a housing advance to include copy of your lease, utility statements, and any other pertinent documentation. Normally, an advance housing allowance may not be paid more than three workdays prior to you being required to make a payment under a lease or payment plan. Repayment will typically be made within 12 months, beginning in the month after receipt of the advance. For example, if you receive a $1,200 advance pay in June, the repayment will begin in July. In this example your repayment amount would $100 per month ($1,200 divided by 12 months equals $100 per month), or $50 per pay period if you get paid twice per month. Alternatively, you may use eFinance to submit your advance pay request electronically.
Regulation: AFMAN 65-116 Vol 1 Chap 35 (PCS Advance Payments) https://www.google.com/url?q=http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/etc/AFMAN65-116V1.pdf&sa=D&ust=1558682437460000&usg=AFQjCNEvkz2swKafpLUtnPxH1wszFbCejA

</616> <617> What type of travel allowances will I receive for a TDY enroute to my new Permanent Duty Station (PDS)? You receive PCS travel allowances from your old PDS to the TDY location, then to your new PDS. In addition, you are authorized TDY allowances at the TDY location. Basic allowances for the TDY will include lodging, Meals and Incidental Expense (M&IE) and the associated reimbursable expenses. Go to the Per Diem Rates for more information. To file your PCS travel settlement voucher, please use eFinance.
